Call of calendar suspended. Last argument of Term on
April 27, 1988.......
Last order of Term on Sept. 30, 1988.......
On June 29, 1988 the Chief Justice announced all cases
submitted have been decided and orders from today's
scheduled conference will be released tomorrow at 10
a.m. Recess to begin June 30th until first Monday in
October at which time October Term 1987 will be ad-
journed and October Term 1988 will begin....

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1986 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed
and the October 1987 Term is now convened."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-1242. City of Akron, et al., Appellants v. Ohio Manufactur-
ers' Association; Akron Selle Company. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-1656. Utah Power & Light Company, Appellant v. Idaho
Public Utilities Commission, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Idaho. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 86-1850. Henry Anderson, Appellant v. Dave Frohnmayer, Wil-
liam F. Gary, James E. Mountain, Jr. and Thomas H. Denney. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 86-1885. John C. Scarvaci, Appellant v. Frederic Matestic, As-
sistant District Attorney, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a pe-
tition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-1891. Michael J. Halliwell, Appellant v. March Fong Eu,
Secretary of State of California, et al. Appeal from the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for

21
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-1899. Earlene Polyak, Appellant v. Thomas Stack and
Henry, Henry and Stack. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-2008. Carl B. Branson, Appellant v. Commissioner of Inter-
nal Revenue. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-2039. Samuel Okin, Appellant v. Commissioner of Internal
Revenue. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-2041. Effie Dell Cassidy, et al., Appellants v. Firestone Tire
& Rubber Company, et al. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of
Florida, First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-2059. Sheriff of Fall River County Jail, et al., Appellants v.
Stanley L. Hughes. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-6977. Sarah Jiminez, Appellant v. Municipal Court, San
Mateo County. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-7142. Charlotte Coats, Appellant v. Stephen Woods, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 86-7149. Lyle Prenzler, Appellant v. Equal Employment
Opportunity Commission. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
3
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-7153. Lyle Prenzler, Appellant v. Social Security Adminis-
tration. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-229. Gwendolyn L. King, Appellant v. California, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-315. William E. Tickel, Jr., Appellant v. Georgia. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-342. Thomas B. Hudgins and Billie E. Billman, Appellants v.
Internal Revenue Service. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5045. John Orin Wulffenstein, Appellant v. Utah. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5062. Mitchell Williams, Appellant v. Georgia. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5168. Louis Brown, Jr., Appellant v. John T. Parnham, Jr.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5188. Twilla Coombs, Appellant v. Metropolitan Federal
Savings and Loan Associations. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
No. 87-5208. Thomas F. Willliams, Appellant v. Philip A. Federico,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5273. Carl Allen Nakagawa, Appellant v. Colorado. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 86-1758. Waterways Association of Pittsburgh, Appellant v.
Herschel H. Rose, III, State Tax Commissioner of West Virginia. Ap-
peal from the Circuit Court of Kanawha County, West Virginia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented federal question.
No. 86-6886. Richard T. Melnick, Appellant v. City of Mentor. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Lake County. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a properly presented federal question.
No. 86-7023. W. L. H., Appellant v. K. B. M. and G. M. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a properly presented federal question.
No. 86-1840. Oliver H. Claypool, Jr., etc., et al., Appellants v.
Elizabeth J. Claypool. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Caro-
lina. The motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 86-1875. DeWeese Nelson Realty, Inc., Appellant v. Equity
Services Co., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 86-1985. Richard B. Freed, et ux., Appellants v. Worcester
County Department of Social Services, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 86-2061. Citizens for Better Education, et al., Appellants v.
Goose Creek Consolidated Independent School District, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Texas, First District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 86-7010. Robert J. Clay, Appellant v. Louis A. Clay, et al. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87–14. Donna Jean Chase, Appellant v. A. J. Schleuning, II.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Oregon. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
5
No. 87-23. Lloyd O. Long, Appellant v. Bradley M. Harrison, a
Minor, by and through his Next Friends and Natural Parents, Michael
L. Harrison, et ux., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-45. James B. Lund, et ux., Appellants v. County of Henne-
pin. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-51. Magdaline M. Hansen, etc., Appellant v. City of San
Buenaventura, California. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Califor-
nia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-86. Richard Wildermuth, Appellant v. Pennsylvania. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87–126. Archdiocesan School Office, et al., Appellants v. Com-
mission on Human Rights and Opportunities. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Connecticut. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 87-141. Ted Poe, Judge of the 228th Judicial District Court of
Harris County, Texas, Appellant v. Robert Jack Collier. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-156. W. T. “Butch” Burns, et al., Appellants v. Chisum Inde-
pendent School District, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Texas, Sixth District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 87-158. Robert N. Berezoski, Appellant v. Ohio. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Montgomery County. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-237. Keith Milton Rhinehart, et al., Appellants v. Tribune
Publishing Company, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Washington, Division 1. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
No. 86-1915. Bohemian Club, Appellant v. Fair Employment and
Housing Commission, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86–2040. Thomas J. Kavanagh, Appellant v. Richard E. Coven.
Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York,

6
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
First Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
No. 87-15. Thomas H. Brown and Debra Brown, Appellants v. Rich-
ard Bailey and Sarah Bailey, et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil
Appeals of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Justice White would dismiss the appeal for want of
jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-1217. Joseph P. Russoniello, et al., Petitioners v. Jose J.
Olagues, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
with instructions that the United States District Court for the North-
ern District of California dismiss the action as moot. United States v.
Munsingwear, 340 U.S. 36 (1950).
No. 86-1419. Oregon Department of Human Resources, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Coos Bay Care Center, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit to consider the suggestion of mootness.
No. 86-1714. Dorothy Arn, Superintendent, Ohio Reformatory for
Women, Petitioner v. Pamela D. Green. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit to consider the question of mootness.
No. 86-1851. William Hapaniewski, Petitioner v. City of Chicago
Heights. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illi-
nois, First District. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Appellate Court of
Illinois, First District, for further consideration in light of Goodman v.
Lukens Steel Company, 482 U.S. — (1987).
No. 86-1855. Delta Air Lines, Inc., and Western Airlines, Inc., Pe-
titioners v. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Ware-
housemen and Helpers of America, Airline Division, et al. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
7
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to consider the question of mootness. Jus-
tice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1898. Illinois, Petitioner v. William Duncan. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. The petition for writ
of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further consideration in
light of Richardson v. Marsh, 481 U.S. (1987).
-
No. 86-1906. Reginald J. Holzer, Petitioner v. United States. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
McNally v. United States, 483 U.S. (1987).
-
No. 86-6641. James Edward Gray, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of the position presently asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief
filed June 17, 1987.
,
No. 87-8. J. Burroughs, et al., Petitioners v. William F. Higgins. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light
of O'Lone v. Estate of Shabazz, 482 U.S. — (1987).
-
No. 87-24. Lawrence Moore and Walter F. Whelan, Jr., Petitioners
v. Bechtel Power Corporation, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of West v. Conrail, 481 U.S.
(1987).
No. 87-28. George W. Pickett, et al., Petitioners v. Edward Joseph
X. Chapman. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for fur-

8
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
ther consideration in light of Anderson v. Creighton, 483 U.S.
(1987).
No. 87-161. Johnny Copeland, Petitioner v. Richard L. Dugger,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The petition for writ
of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Hitchcock v. Dugger, 481 U.S. (1987).

and defendant is allowed sixty days within which to file an answer.

petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner
is allowed until October 26, 1987, within which to pay the docketing fee

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
11
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed
in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of mandamus without reaching the merits of the mo-
tion to proceed in forma pauperis.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice
Powell (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit during the period of October 5
through October 9, 1987, and for such further time as may be required
to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 294(a), is
ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
Sec. 295.
ORDER
The order of July 31, 1987, assigning the Chief Justice to the Fifth
Circuit as Circuit Justice is vacated.

The Chief Justice said:
"Before I call the first case for argument, I would like to make a part
of the record of this Court an exchange of correspondence between the
Court and Justice Powell upon his retirement. Our letter to Justice
Powell which is signed by his eight colleagues and his response will be
made a part of the Journal of today's proceedings."
Our letter to Justice Powell reads as follows:
Supreme Court of the United States,
Washington, D.C., June 29, 1987.
Chambers of the Chief Justice
Dear Lewis,
You know without our telling you again how saddened we are by your
departure from our ranks. For more than fifteen years we have bene-
fited from your wise and careful marshaling of arguments in Confer-
ence, and from your shouldering Term after Term of more than your
share of the Court's opinion writing. All of us admire your extraordi-
nary capacity to forcefully participate in our private and public debates
without ever allowing advocacy to degenerate into contentiousness.
Your career in the legal profession before coming here was replete
with laurels. Thirty years of successful law practice, wartime service
overseas in Air Force Intelligence, President of the American Bar As-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1987
89
sociation, President of the Richmond School Board were but some of
your accomplishments. The lessons from a life so rich in experience in-
formed your judgment as a member of the Court.
We bid you a fond farewell as you retire from this last arena in which
you have served your profession and served your country. We are
grateful for, and look forward to, the prospect of your continued
companionship in the future.
Affectionately,
William H. Rehnquist.
William J. Brennan, Jr.
Byron R. White.
Thurgood Marshall.
Harry A. Blackmun.
John Paul Stevens.
Sandra O'Connor.
Antonin Scalia
Justice Powell's response reads as follows:
Supreme Court of the United States,
Washington, D.C., July 10, 1987.
Chambers of Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr. (Retired)
Dear Colleagues:
Your gracious letter of June 29 was forwarded to me here in Rich-
mond. It is a letter I am proud to share with Jo and our children, and
one I shall always treasure.
I can add little to what I said in my statement of June 26. I do leave
the Court with a considerable measure of sadness. I have been privi-
leged to serve on a strong Court, and also I have cherished the friend-
ship I have shared with each of you. This, of course, will continue al-
though I will miss more than I can say the day to day participation in
the work of the Court.
With admiration and affection for each of you.
Sincerely,
Lewis.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-5638. Walter Bell, Jr., Petitioner v. James A. Lynaugh, Jr.,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White and by him
referred to the Court is denied by an equally divided Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-5546. Donald Gene Franklin, Petitioner v. James A.
Lynaugh, Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit is granted limited to Question 3 presented by the petition.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 87-5359. Jeffery Joseph Daugherty, Petitioner v. Florida. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is denied. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida is denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1987
97
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
"
No. 87–137. Stephen C. Morin, Appellant v. Steven Petrarca. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Rhode Island. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-265. Walter Lee Kimberlin, Appellant v. Oklahoma. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-302. The Aquarian Foundation and Keith Milton Rhinehart,
Appellants v. Law Offices of Edwards & Barbieri. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87–404. Mickey Manuel, Appellant v. Robert Hudgens, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5150. Gary Baronowski, Appellant v. The Unconstitutionality
of Two Subsections of the Privacy Act, etc., et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 9, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of Loui-
siana, et al. The motion of the United States for leave to file a reply to
the Exceptions of Mississippi, out-of-time, is granted. The Exceptions
to the Report of the Special Master are set for oral argument in due
course. The motion of the Special Master for additional compensation
and reimbursement of expenses, as set forth in the motion, is granted

98
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1987
and it is ordered that such costs be borne equally by the United States
and Mississippi. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or
decision of these motions.
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. James A.
Baker, III, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. The motion
of South Carolina for divided argument to permit National Governors'
Association to present oral argument as intervenor and the motion of
National Governors' Association for divided argument are granted. The
requests for additional time for oral argument are denied.
No. D-634. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Jackson Bryan. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-639. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerald Mark Goldberg.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-655. In the Matter of Disbarment of Roger A. Wood. It is
ordered that Roger A. Wood, of Toledo, Ohio, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-656. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Albert Friedman. It
is ordered that John Albert Friedman, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-657. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerome Bernard Rosen-
thal. It is ordered that Jerome Bernard Rosenthal, of Los Angeles,
California, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-658. In the Matter of Disbarment of James E. Robinson. It is
ordered that James E. Robinson, of Houston, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 86-492. Delbert Boyle, Personal Representative of the heirs and
Estate of David A. Boyle, Deceased, Petitioner v. United Technologies
Corporation. The motion of Edwin Lees Shaw for leave to submit sup-
plemental authority as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 86-1172. Goodyear Atomic Corporation, Appellant v. Esto Miller
and Industrial Commission of Ohio. The motion of appellees for divided
argument is denied.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1987
99
No. 86-6139. Clara Watson, Petitioner v. Fort Worth Bank and
Trust. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied.
No. 87-318. Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Division, United Technologies
Corporation, Petitioner v. Christine Baldracchi. The motion of Jonna
Lingle for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 87-405. In Re Janice C. Yee. The application for stay and other
relief addressed to Justice Scalia and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 87-5315. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner v. Board of Directors,
Whitney M. Young, Jr., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November
3, 1987, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a)
and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the rea-
sons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we
would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5353. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner v. Otis R. Bowen, Secre-
tary of Health and Human Services. The motion of petitioner for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until No-
vember 3, 1987, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule
45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of
this Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983),
we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5508. Norma Jean Almodovar, Petitioner v. California. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court is denied.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 19, 1987, until
Monday, November 2, 1987.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 86-228. Juozas Kungys, Petitioner v. United States. Argued by
Mr. Donald J. Williamson for the petitioner and by Mr. Robert H.
Klonoff for the respondent.
No. 86–492. Delbert Boyle, Personal Representative of the heirs and
Estate of David A. Boyle, Deceased, Petitioner v. United Technologies
Corporation. Argued by Mr. Louis Stanton Franecke for the petitioner,
by Mr. Philip A. Lacovara for the respondent, and by Mr. Donald B.
Ayer for the United States, as amicus curiae in support of the respond-
ent by special leave of Court.
No. 86-836. Hazelwood School District, et al., Petitioners v. Cathy
Kuhlmeier, et al. Argued by Mr. Robert P. Baine, Jr., for petitioners
and by Ms. Leslie D. Edwards for the respondents.
No. 86-651. United Paperworkers International Union, AFL-CIO,
et al., Petitioners v. Misco, Inc. Argued by Mr. David Silberman for the
petitioners and by Mr. A. Richard Gear for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1987
121
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 87-75. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Robert
McCoy, Executor of the Estate of Arthur H. McCoy, Deceased. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-307. Lee Anthony Kondor, Appellant v. Pennsylvania. Ap-
peal from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Office. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-314. Quality Markets, Inc., Appellant v. Pennsylvania. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-345. In Re Julia McCain Lampkin Asam, Appellant. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari and the petition for writ of mandamus are denied.
No. 87–390. In Re Julia McCain Lampkin Asam, Appellant. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari and the petition for writ of mandamus are denied.
No. 87-398. Russ Building Partnership, Appellant v. City and
County of San Francisco, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction.

122
MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1987
No. 87-5378. Ernest R. Andregg, Appellant v. Pacific Telephone
and Telegraph Company, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, Third Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5439. Norman Lewis Dehnhoff, Appellant v. Barbara Vin-
yard, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87–146. Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., Inc., et al., Peti-
tioners v. Edward J. Adrian, et ux. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit for further consideration in light of Shearson/American
Express, Inc. v. McMahon, 482 U.S. (1987).
-
No. 87–169. Charles J. Scully, et al., Petitioner v. Yevgen Fromer.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of O'Lone v. Estate of Shabazz, 482 U.S. - - (1987)
and Turner v. Safley, 482 U.S. (1987).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-265. John Lorenzini and Nancy Lorenzini, Applicants v. New
Jersey, et al. The application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-284. Jerome B. Rosenthal, Applicant v. State Bar of Cali-
fornia. The application for stay and other relief addressed to Justice
Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-651. In the Matter of Disbarment of Vincent Paul Rigolosi.
The motion to defer filing a response to the Rule to Show Cause is
denied.
No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
It is ordered that Arthur L. Littleworth, Esquire, of Riverside, Cali-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1987
123
fornia, be appointed Special Master in place of the Honorable Wade
H. McCree, Jr., deceased.
The Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and conditions
for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceed-
ings, and authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take
such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it neces-
sary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit such reports
as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
No. 86-181. Patricia A. Dixon, Petitioner v. Westinghouse Electric
Corporation. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a
supplemental brief, as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 86-728. Bill Honig, California Superintendent of Public Instruc-
tion, Petitioner v. John Doe and Jack Smith. The motion of the Solicitor
General to permit Glen D. Nager, Esquire, to present oral argument
pro hac vice is granted.
No. 86-1512. Samuel R. Pierce, Jr., Secretary of Housing and
Urban Development, Petitioner v. Myrna Underwood, et al. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix
is granted.
No. 86-1602. United Savings Association of Texas, Petitioner v.
Timbers of Inwood Forest Associates, Inc. The motion of Global
Marine, Inc. for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus
curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral argument
is denied.
No. 86-1650. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Independent
Federation of Flight Attendants. The motion of American Federation
of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 87-376. Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission, Peti-
tioner v. National Basketball Association, et al. The motion of the
parties to defer consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted.
No. 87-544. Philip Coombe, Superintendent, Eastern Correctional
Facility, Petitioner v. Robert Escalera. The application of Robert

OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 86-656. Ronald W. Reagan, et al., Petitioners v. James
Abourezk, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeal for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed by
an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief
Justice. Justice Blackmun took no part in the decision of this case.
Justice Scalia took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Х
Adjourned until Monday, November 2, 1987, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1987
139
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-5699. Andrew L. Jones, Petitioner v. Hilton Butler, Warden.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death, presented to
Justice White and by him referred to the Court, is granted pending the
disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1987
141
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87–230. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Appellant v. Jeanne A. Jordan, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 87-411. Arturo Casillas and Omero P. Luna, Appellants v.
Texas. Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-439. Frederick J. Encalade, Vergie T. Encalade and Irvin A.
Cross, Appellants v. Louisiana. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
Louisiana, Fourth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 87-414. Earlene Polyak, Appellant v. William Boston and Bos-
ton, Bates and Holt. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5523. Daniel R. DeNardo, Petitioner v. Alaska. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Alaska. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-5231. Melvin Max Malone, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of the

142
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1987
position presently asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief filed
October 5, 1987. The Chief Justice dissents.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Clark-Cowlitz Joint Operating Agency, Petitioner v. Fed-
eral Energy Regulatory Commission. The motion for leave to dispense
with printing portions of the appendix to the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari is denied. Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens and Justice O'Con-
nor would grant the motion. Justice Scalia took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion.
No. -. James Leo Greene, Petitioner v. Friend of the Court, Polk
County, Iowa, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for
a writ of certiorari which does not comply with the Rules of the Court is
denied.
-
No. . Marvin Miller, Petitioner v. California. The motion to direct
the Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-289. Wilma J. and Daniel Gilbert, Applicants v. Superior
Court of California, Tulare County, et al. The application for stay
addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-642. In the Matter of Disbarment of Raul Palomo, Jr. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-648. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Monoker. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-649. In the Matter of Disbarment of Fred F. Filsoof. Fred F.
Filsoof, of Atlanta, Georgia, having requested to resign as a member of
the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on July 29, 1987, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-659. In the Matter of Disbarment of George P. Shirley. It is
ordered that George P. Shirley, of Pebble Beach, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of Loui-
siana, et al. The motion of Alaska for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment as amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1987
143
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. James A.
Baker, III, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. It is
ordered that the Honorable Matthew J. Jasen, Retired, of Buffalo, New
York, be appointed Special Master in place of the Honorable Samuel J.
Roberts, deceased.
The Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and conditions
for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceed-
ings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and
take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it
necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit such
reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
No. 104, Original. State of New Jersey, Plaintiff v. State of Nevada,
the Nevada Public Service Commission and the City of Las Vegas, Ne-
vada. It is ordered that Ralph I. Lancaster, Jr., Esquire, of Portland,
Maine, be appointed Special Master in place of the Honorable Wade H.
McCree, Jr., deceased.
The Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and conditions
for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceed-
ings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and
take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it
necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit such
reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
No. 86-1357. United States Department of Justice, et al., Petitioners
v. Kenneth Michael Julian and Margaret J. Wallace. The motion of re-
spondent Margaret J. Wallace for leave to proceed further herein in
forma pauperis is granted.
No. 86-1552. Department of the Navy, Petitioner v. Thomas E.
Egan. The motion of Ralph B. Bogdanowicz for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument and for addi-
tional time for oral argument is denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1987

No. 87-4. Mark Erick Wheat, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix is denied.

to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 87-382. State Tax Commission of the State of New York, et al.,
Petitioners v. Herzog Brothers Trucking, Inc., etc., et al. The Solicitor
General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the
United States.
No. 87-535. Christopher DeBock, Petitioner v. Florida. The applica-
tion to continue stay of proceedings addressed to the Chief Justice and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. 87-5411. In Re Mitsuko Shibuya, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is
allowed until November 23, 1987, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and
Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of mandamus without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5425. Kenneth O. Roberts, Petitioner v. Cathy Roberts. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until November 23, 1987, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1987
145
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5436. William D. Jones, Petitioner 2. Farm Credit Adminis-
tration. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 23, 1987, within which
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting:
For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1987
169
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87–100. John J. Lynch and Joseph S. Wright, Sr., etc., Appel-
lants v. City of Chicago, et al. Appeal from the Appellate Court of
Illinois, First District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 87-441. Mary Scott Blake Birdsall, et al., Appellants v. Thomas
R. Shepherd, Jr., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-456. Maude Clevenger Sim, Appellant v. Opal C. Comiskey,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-446. Kenneth Paul Keller, Appellant v. Oklahoma. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-645. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Edwin Freuden-
berg. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-653. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul A. Vaughn. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-660. In the Matter of Disbarment of William F. Schuler. It is
ordered that William F. Schuler, of San Francisco, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-661. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur J. Sullivan. It is
ordered that Arthur J. Sullivan, of Wilmington, Delaware, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,

170
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1987
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-662. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert J. Vavrik. It is
ordered that Robert J. Vavrik, of McHenry, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 86-935. Regents of the University of California, Appellant v.
Public Employment Relations Board, et al. The motion of National
Education Association, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted.
No. 86-1013. Richard E. Lyng, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Northwest Indian Cemetery Protective Association, et al.
The motion of respondents for leave to file out-of-time motion for
divided argument is denied.
No. 86-1992. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Antolin Punsalan Pangilinan, et al.; and
No. 86-2019. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Bonifacio Lorenzana Manzano. The motion of the Solicitor General to
dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 87-205. Alaska Miners Association, Petitioner v. Trustees for
Alaska, et al.;
No. 87-206. Alaska, Petitioner v. Trustees for Alaska, et al.; and
No. 87-371. Trustees of Alaska, et al., Petitioners v. Alaska, et al.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases expressing
the views of the United States.
No. 87–482. Easter Seal Society for Crippled Children and Adults of
Louisiana, Inc., Petitioner v. Playboy Enterprises, Inc., et al. The
Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 87-453. Amerada Hess Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Direc-
tor, Division of Taxation, New Jersey Department of the Treasury; and
No. 87-464. Texaco, Inc. and Tenneco Oil Company, Appellants v.
Director, Division of Taxation, New Jersey Department of the Treas-
ury. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases
expressing the views of the United States. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.

No. 87-375. Geoffrey Monge, Sheriff of Sarasota County, Florida, et
al., Petitioners v. Michael Dennis Straub. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.
The Chief Justice took no part in the consideration or decision of this

No. 87-447. Ronald D. Castille, District Attorney, Philadelphia
County, Petitioner v. Martin Harris, et al. The motion of respondents
Harris, et al. for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit denied.
No. 87-5077. George E. Brooks, Jr., Petitioner v. Louisiana. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 87-5170. John C. McCulloch, Petitioner v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White in this
case and in No. 87-5266, post, with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 87-5266. Jerry Herbert Jones, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White in this
case and in No. 87-5170, ante, with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 87-5298. Leonard Finestone, Petitioner v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit denied. Justice White would grant certiorari.
No. 87-5505. Darrell Gene Devier, Petitioner v. Ralph Kemp, War-
den. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Geor-
gia denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice
Brennan joins.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 87-5502. In Re Ernest E. Gilbert, Petitioner. The petition for
writ of mandamus and/or prohibition is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 86-6846. James Cleveland, Petitioner v. Warden, Maryland
House of Corrections;
No. 86-6863. Raymond Rochon, Petitioner v. Acadia Parish Sheriff
Department, et al.; and
No. 87-5232. James Earl Williams, Petitioner v. Tim Joiner. The
petitions for rehearing are denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1987
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
177
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice
Powell (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit during the period of January 4
through January 8, 1988, and for such further time as may be required
to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Section 294(a),
is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C.
Section 295.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, November 16, 1987, until
Monday, November 30, 1987.

and Justice Scalia.

No. 86-472. Church of Scientology of California, Petitioner v. Inter-
nal Revenue Service. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by the Chief Justice. Justice Brennan and Justice Scalia took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.

No. A-374. Richard L. Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Applicant v. Bennie E. Demps. The application of the
Attorney General of Florida for an order to vacate the stay of execution
of sentence of death entered by the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred
to the Court is denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1987
187
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87–10. Stanley Boclair and Joel T. Pelz, Appellants v. Illinois.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-531. Julia McCain Lampkin Asam, Appellant v. Lee County
District School Board, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5539. Bobbie Lee Adams, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal from
the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-608. Helmer T. Pederson, Appellant v. Sylvan Shulman.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 87-5547. William Fischer, Appellant v. Michigan. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-337. James M. Williams, Applicant v. Minnesota Lawyers
Professional Responsibility Board. The application for a temporary
restraining order addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-651. In the Matter of Disbarment of Vincent Paul Rigolosi.
Disbarment order entered.
No. 86-1034. Virginia, Appellant v. American Booksellers Associa-
tion, Inc., et al. The motion of appellees for leave to file a supplemental
brief after argument is granted.

188
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1987
No. 86-1172. Goodyear Atomic Corporation, Appellant v. Esto Miller
and Industrial Commission of Ohio. The motion of Oil, Chemical and
Atomic Workers International Union for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted.
No. 86-1357. United States Department of Justice, et al., Petitioners
v. Kenneth Michael Julian and Margaret J. Wallace. The motion of the
Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 86-1415. Evelyn Marino, et al., Petitioners v. Juan U. Ortiz,
et al.; and Wayne Costello, Petitioners et al.; v. New York City Police
Department, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit Glen
D. Nager, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 86-7009. In Re Mitsuko Shibuya, Petitioner;
No. 86-7012. In Re Mitsuko Shibuya, Petitioner; and
No. 87-5032. In Re Mitsuko Shibuya, Petitioner. The motion of
petitioner for reconsideration of orders denying motions for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 87–170. William Copely, et ux., et al., Appellants v. Heil-Quaker
Corp., et al. The motion of appellants to expedite consideration and/or
consolidate this case with No. 87-367, Bendix Autolite Corp. v.
Midwesco Enterprises, is denied.
No. 87-454. The Dominican Republic and Instituto de Auxilios y
Vivienda, Petitioners v. Charles V. Meadows, deceased, and George
Harris. The application for stay addressed to Justice Stevens and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. 87-5489. James G. Bennett, Petitioner v. North American Van
Lines, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until December 7, 1987, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-505. Chick Kam Choo, et al., Petitioners v. Exxon Corpora-
tion, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1987
207
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-340. Gerald W. Wyant, Appellant v. Pennsylvania Depart-
ment of Environmental Resources, et al. Appeal from the Common-
wealth Court of Pennsylvania. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-588. Peabody Coal Company, Appellant v. State Tax Com-
mission of Missouri, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-5634. Steve Wool, Appellant, v. Steve Richardson, et al. Ap-
peal from the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-579. Harry Katz, Appellant v. New York. Appeal from the
Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial De-
partment. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 87–625. S. A. Schapiro, Appellant v. Heritage Mutual Insurance
Company. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District I.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87–637. Cassandra Green, Appellant v. Aram Franklin. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-5596. Charlotte Ann Coats Armstrong, Appellant v. William
Craig Armstrong. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-650. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Simon Slotkin. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-663. In the Matter of Disbarment of Victor F. Ciardelli. It is
ordered that Victor F. Ciardelli, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 110, Original. In the Matter of the Republic of Suriname, Ex
Rel. Etienne Boerenveen, Petitioner. The motion for leave to file a pe-
tition for writ of habeas corpus is denied.
No. 86-1034. Virginia, Appellant v. American Booksellers Associa-
tion, Inc., et al. The motion of appellant for leave to file a supplemental
brief after argument is granted.
No. 86-6139. Clara Watson, Petitioner v. Fort Worth Bank and
Trust. The motion of Texas for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied.
No. 87–333. Delta Air Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Port Authority of
New York and New Jersey. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 87-731. Globe Newspaper Company and David Farrell, Petition-
ers v. Edward J. King. The motion of respondent to vacate the stay
granted by Justice Brennan is denied.
No. 87-5454. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner v. Sylvester M. Gould, Jr.,
et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until December 21, 1987, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5772. William Alexander Lewis, et al., Petitioners v. United
States. The motion of petitioners to expedite consideration of the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is denied.

no part in the consideration or decision of of this petition.

227
No. 86-1013. Richard E. Lyng, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Northwest Indian Cemetery Protective Association, et al.

lyn B. Miles for the respondents.

Center, Inc., dba Heights Hospital, et al. Argued by Mr. Bruce Ian
Schimmel for the appellant and by Mr. Jack E. Urquhart for the
appellees.
No. 86-1415. Evelyn Marino, et al., Petitioners v. Juan U. Ortiz, et
al.; and Wayne Costello, et al., Petitioners v. New York City Police
Department, et al. Argued by Mr. Ronald Podolsky for the petitioners,
by Mr. Gled D. Nager, pro hac vice, for the United States as amicus
curiae, supporting petitioners, by special leave of Court, and by Mr.
Leonard J. Koerner for the respondents.

Lloyd M. Crenshaw. Argued by Mr. Theodore B. Olson for the appel-
lant and by Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr., for the appellee.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1987
229
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia.
OPINIONS
No. 86–489. W. T. Langley, et ux., Petitioners v. Federal Deposit
Insurance Corporation. On writ to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 85-1551. Alan J. Karcher, Speaker of the New Jersey General
Assembly, et al., Appellants v. Jeffrey May, et al. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Appeal dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Jus-
tice White concurring in the judgment.
No. 86-473. Gwaltney of Smithfield, Petitioner v. Chesapeake Bay
Foundation, Inc. and Natural Resources Defense Council. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Marshall. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Stevens and Justice
O'Connor join.
No. 86-651. United Paperworkers International Union, AFL-CIO,
et al., Petitioners v. Misco, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Con-
curring opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan joins.
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 86-1128. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Assibi Abudu. Argued by Mr. Robert H. Klonoff for the petitioner and
Ms. Dorothy A. Harper for the respondent.
No. 86-787. Cecil Hicks, District Attorney for County of Orange,
California, Acting on Behalf of Alta Sue Feiock, Petitioner v. Phillip
William Feiock. Argued by Michael R. Capizzi for the petitioner and by
Mr. Richard Lynn Schwartzberg for the respondent.

230
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1987
No. 86-1512. Samuel R. Pierce, Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development, Petitioner v. Myrna Underwood, et al. Argued by Mr.
Thomas W. Merrill for the petitioner and by Ms. Mary S. Burdick for
the respondents.
No. 86-1602. United Savings Association of Texas, Petitioner v. Tim-
bers of Inwood Forest Associates, Inc. Argued by Mr. H. Miles Cohn
for the petitioner and by Mr. Leonard H. Simon for the respondent.
ORDER
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28 U.S.C. Section 42, it is ordered
that Justice Stevens be, and he is hereby, assigned to the Eleventh Cir-
cuit as Circuit Justice, pending further order. The order of September
10, 1987, assigning Justice O'Connor to the Eleventh Circuit as Circuit
Justice is vacated.
Х
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1987
233
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-5669. Richard G. Alberton, Appellant v. State Bar of Califor-
nia. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87–635. Oklahoma Tax Commission, Petitioner v. Jan Graham,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Caterpillar Inc. v. Williams, 482 U.S.
(1987).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. James Fisher, Jr., Petitioner v. Oklahoma. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of
indigency executed by the petitioner is granted.
No. D-652. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald R. Conway. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-664. In the Matter of Disbarment of John A. Wittmaack. It is
ordered that John A. Wittmaack, of Hawley, Pennsylvania, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-665. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul J. Enrico. It is or-
dered that Paul J. Enrico, of West Babylon, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

234
MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1987
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Excep-
tions to the Report, with supporting briefs, may be filed by the parties
within 45 days. Replies thereto, with supporting briefs, may be filed
within 30 days.
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. James A.
Baker, III, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. The motion.
for compensation on behalf of the Estate of the Special Master, Samuel
J. Roberts, is granted.
No. 87–201. Gerald E. Mansell, Appellant v. Gaye Mansell Forbes.
The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 87-609. Shell Oil Company, Appellant v. Director of Revenue of
Missouri. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
No. 87-5411. In Re Mitsuko Shibuya, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for reconsideration of the order of Court denying the motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 87-5500. Ralph Tiller, et al., Petitioners v. NCNB Bank of North
Carolina. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until December 28, 1987, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5648. Mitsuko Shibuya, Petitioner v. Paul Voss, et al. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until December 28, 1987, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall, and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion.
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5659. John E. Tischio, Appellant v. New Jersey. The motion
of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Appellant
is allowed until December 28, 1987, within which to pay the docketing

MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1987
235
fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a statement as to jurisdiction
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would
dismiss the appeal for want of a substantial federal question without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-354. Arizona, Petitioner v. Ronald William Roberson. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Arizona,
Division Two, granted.
No. 87-416. United States Catholic Conference, et al., Petitioners v.
Abortion Rights Mobilization, Inc., et al. The motion of National Coun-
cil of Churches of Christ in the U.S.A., et al. for leave to fill a brief as
amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
No. 87-5367. Ralph Mills, Petitioner v. Maryland. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland granted.

Argued by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the appellant and by Mr. Rob-
ert H. Rotstein for the appellees.
The Chief Justice said:
"Mr. Wallace, our records show that this is your 100th appearance
before this Court and that your first argument here was in a case ar-

248
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1987
gued on March 25, 1968 for the government. On behalf of the Court, I
would like to extend to you our thanks for able advocacy during this
period of time."
ORDER
It is ordered that Rule 35.3 of the Rules of the Supreme Court of the
United States be amended to read as follows:
"35.3. A reply brief will be received within 30 days after the filing of
the brief for the appellee or respondent, or not later than one week be-
fore the date of oral argument, whichever is earlier, and only by leave
of Court thereafter."
The foregoing amendment shall become effective immediately, ex-
cept that in a case in which the brief for the appellee or respondent has
already been filed, a reply brief will be received within 30 days of this
order, or not later than one week before the date of oral argument,
whichever is earlier.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
