SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-639. Paul F. Perati, Appellant v. Joseph Buell, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-5698. Ericke Eckert, Appellant v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-658. W. Kenneth Ross, et ux., Appellants v. City of Rolling
Hills Estates, Inc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a prop-
erly presented federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-583. United Paperworkers International Union, AFL-CIO,
No. 1069, Petitioner v. S. D. Warren Company. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit for further consideration in light of United Paperworkers
International Union, AFL-CIO v. Misco, Inc., 484 U.S. - (1987).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 85-1765. Bankers Life and Casualty Company, Appellant v.
Lloyd M. Crenshaw. The conditional motion of appellee for leave to file
a supplemental brief after argument is granted. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

252
MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1987
No. 86-1052. Volkswagenwerk Aktiengesellschaft, Petitioner v.
Herwig J. Schlunk, Administrator of Estates of Franz J. Schlunk and
Sylvia Schlunk, Deceased. The motion of petitioner to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 86-1406. Puerto Rico Department of Consumer Affairs, et al.,
Petitioners v. Isla Petroleum Corporation, et al. The motion of the So-
licitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus cu-
riae and for divided argument is granted. Justice O'Connor took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 86-1743. Monessen Southwestern Railway Company, Appellant
v. Gerald L. Morgan. The motion of Association of American Railroads
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 87-65. United States, Petitioner v. Providence Journal Company
and Charles M. Hauser. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument
is denied.
No. 87-323. Vladimir Sokolov, etc., Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner to defer consideration of the petition for a writ of
certiorari is granted.
No. 87-329. The Florida Star, Appellant v. B. J. F. Because this ap-
peal involves a question of law of the State of Florida which is determi-
native of this cause and for which there is no controlling precedent of
the Supreme Court of Florida, this Court, pursuant to Article V, Sec-
tion 3(b)(6) of the Florida Constitution, certifies to the Supreme Court
of Florida and respectfully requests that Court to answer, the following
question: Whether the Florida Supreme Court had jurisdiction, pursu-
ant to Article V, Section 3(b)(3) of the Florida Constitution or other-
wise, to hear Appellant's appeal in this cause from the Florida First
District Court of Appeal? It is further ORDERED: That the Clerk of
this Court shall transmit to the Supreme Court of Florida certified
copies of this order and the briefs filed in this Court in this matter; And
it is further ORDERED: That this Court shall retain jurisdiction of this
matter and that the proceedings in this Court shall be held in abeyance
until further order of this Court.
No. 87-636. Efthimios A. Karahalios, Petitioner v. National Federa-
tion of Federal Employees, Local 1263. The Solicitor General is invited
to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 87-652. Alberta Gas Chemicals Limited, et al., Petitioners v.
E. I. DuPont de Nemours and Company, et al. The Solicitor General is

MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1987
253
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 87-5565. Cherlyn Clark, Petitioner v. Gene Jeter. The motion of
Women's Legal Defense Fund for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
is granted.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 87–654. New Energy Company of Indiana, Appellant v. Joanne
Limbach, Tax Commissioner of Ohio, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Ohio. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

sociation of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
granted limited to Question 2 presented by the petition.

dustries Operating Corp. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted limited to
Question 1 presented by the petition. In addition to this question, the
parties are directed to brief and argue the following question: Did the
United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit have jurisdic-
tion of the appeal from the district court judgment entered on July 19,
1985?

OPINIONS
No. 86-594. National Labor Relations Board and Rosemary M.
Collyer, General Counsel, National Labor Relations Board, Petitioners
v. United Food and Commercial Workers Union, Local 23, AFL-CIO.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals with instructions to dismiss the cause for want of subject-
matter jurisdiction. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion
by Justice Scalia with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White and Jus-
tice O'Connor join.
No. 86-327. Mullins Coal Company, Inc. of Virginia, et al., Petition-
ers v. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, United
States Department of Labor, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens an-
nounced by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall
with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 85-673. Neil F. Hartigan, Attorney General of the State of Illi-
nois, etc., et al., Appellants v. David Zbaraz and Allan G. Charles, etc.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-

MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1987
263
cuit. Judgment below is affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion
per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.
No. 86-1108. Vermont, Petitioner v. Rick Cox. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Vermont. The writ of certiorari is dismissed as
improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief
Justice.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JANUARY 7, 1988
265
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-527. Robert L. Streetman, Applicant v. James A. Lynaugh,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of the sentence of death, presented to Justice White and by
him referred to the Court, is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution of
sentence of death.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1988
267
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS
SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-343. Montana, et al., Appellants v. Crow Tribe of Indians, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. The judgment is affirmed. The Chief Justice would note probable
jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 87-719. Patrick Curtis Martin, Appellant v. Georgia Department
of Public Safety, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied. Justice Brennan would postpone further consideration of
the question of jurisdiction to the hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 87-720. Ethel Hagen, etc., Appellant v. South Dakota, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of South Dakota. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction.
No. 87-756. Thomas Lee Chapman, Appellant v. Florida. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a pe-
tition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-779. Raymond Dobard, Appellant v. City of Oakland, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-5625. Michael August, Appellant v. County of Los Angeles.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5731. Daniel R. De Nardo, Appellant v. Thomas K. Williams,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth

268
MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1988
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5837. Jack Z. Boyd, Jr., Appellant v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 87-5872. Thomas E. Spychala, Appellant v. Paul J. Morris, War-
den. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-960. Edward A. Loss, III, Appellant v. The Supreme Court
of Illinois and The Illinois State Board of Law Examiners. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 87-5504. James Sarlund, Appellant v. Wisconsin. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 87-5903. Reinaldo Moya-Gomez, Appellant v. Wisconsin. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District I. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a properly presented federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-653. Government of the Virgin Islands, Petitioner v. JDS
Realty Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit to consider
the question of mootness.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Ruth Cooper, Petitioner v. Ben Rubin, Jr. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time,
is denied.
-
No. . Antonio Mareno, Petitioner v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is
denied.

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1988
269
No. American Petrofina Company of Texas, Petitioner v. Oil,
Chemical & Atomic Workers International Union, Local No. 4-23, et al.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.
No. A-438. Jose A. Perez and Nancy C. Perez, Applicants v. United
States. The application for stay addressed to the Chief Justice and re-
ferred to the Court is denied.
No. A-491. Georgetown University, et al., Applicants v. Gay Rights
Coalition of Georgetown University Law Center, et al. The application
for stay presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court
is denied. The orders entered December 24, 1987 and December 31,
1987, in this case are vacated. Justice Scalia took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this application.
No. D-666. In the Matter of Disbarment of M. Patrick Keehan. It is
ordered that M. Patrick Keehan, of Towson, Maryland, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable.
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 86-958. Norwest Bank Worthington, et al., Petitioners v. James
R. Ahlers, et ux. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a reply brief,
out-of-time, is denied.
No. 86-1052. Volkswagenwerk Aktiengesellschaft, Petitioner v.
Herwig J. Schlunk, Administrator of Estates of Franz J. Schlunk and
Sylvia Schlunk, Deceased. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave
to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argu-
ment is granted.
No. 86-1970. Mississippi Power & Light Company, Appellant v. Mis-
sissippi ex rel. Edwin Lloyd Pittman, Attorney General of Mississippi,
and Mississippi Legal Services Coalition. The motion of the Solicitor
General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and
for divided argument is granted.
No. 86-6124. George S. Bennett, Petitioner v. Arkansas. The motion
of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 86-1145. Timothy A. Patrick, Petitioner v. William M. Burget,
et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

270
MONDAY, JANUARY 11. 1988
No. 86-1430. R. "Roy" Peralta, Appellant v. Heights Medical Center,
Inc., dba Heights Hospital, et al. The motion of appellee for leave to file
a supplemental brief after argument is denied.
No. 86-1685. Florida, et al., Petitioners v. Hughlan Long, et al. The
motion of Equal Employment Advisory Council, et al. for leave to file a
brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 86-7113. Paula Kadrmas, et al., Appellants v. Dickinson Public
Schools, et al. The motion of North Dakota for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
The motion of appellees to dismiss appeal is denied.
No. 87–16. Richard D. Shapero, Petitioner v. Kentucky Bar Associa-
tion. The motion of The Academy of Florida Trial Lawyers for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Florida Bar for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 87-65. United States, Petitioner v. Providence Journal Company
and Charles M. Hauser. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Further consideration of the
motion of respondent to dismiss the writ of certiorari is deferred to the
hearing of the case on the merits. This case will be heard on oral argu-
ment January 20, 1988, in place of No. 86-1387, Mackey, et al. v. La-
nier Collections Agency.
No. 87-82. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Appellant v.
James E. Mallen, et al. The motion of appellee James E. Mallen for
leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 87-363. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Petitioner v.
Martin Exploration Management Company, et al.; and
No. 87-364. Public Service Commission of New York, et al., Petition-
ers v. Martin Exploration Management Company, et al. The motion of
the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 87-517. Cecil Coe and Peter Poe, Petitioners v. United States.
The motion of petitioners for leave to file lower court orders under seal
is granted.
No. 87-600. Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Beverly J. Otto, etc. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 87-5096. Quincy West, Petitioner v. Samuel Atkins. The motion
of American Public Health Association for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted.

MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1988
271
No. 87-5461. Charles R. Henson, Petitioner v. East Lincoln Town-
ship, et al. The motion of the parties to defer further proceedings is
granted for sixty (60) days.
No. 87-5794. In Re John Reardon, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is
allowed until February 1, 1988, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for writ of mandamus
and/or prohibition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of man-
damus and/or prohibition without reaching the merits of the motion to
proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-5840. Edward McNamara, Appellant v. County of San Diego
Department of Adoptions. The motion of appellant for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is denied. Appellant is allowed until February 1,
1988, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and
to submit a statement as to jurisdiction in compliance with Rule 33 of
the Rules of this Court.
APPEALS
JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED

Kendrick, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. The
case is consolidated with No. 87- 253, Bowen v. Kendrick, No. 87-431,
Bowen v. Kendrick and No. 87-462, Kendrick v. Bowen. A total of one
hour is allotted for oral argument in these cases.

and Robert C. Braun. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Further consideration of the question of juris-
diction is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1988
305
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia.
OPINIONS
No. 86-761. Cynthia A. Forrester, Petitioner v. Howard Lee White.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Justice Blackmun joins in all but
Part II of this opinion.
No. 86-6060. Dale Robert Yates, Petitioner v. James Aiken, War-
den, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Stevens.
No. 86-890. Dean Deakins, et al., Petitioners v. William Monaghan,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment is affirmed in part and vacated in part and the
case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Justice White with whom Justice O'Connor
joins.
No. 86-964. David A. Thompson, Petitioner v. Susan A. Thompson,
aka Susan A. Clay. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Marshall. Statement by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and con-
curring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the
judgment.

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1988
307
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia
OPINIONS
No. 86-714. Rodney P. Westfall, et al., Petitioners v. William T.
Erwin, Sr., and Emely Erwin. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 86-836. Hazelwood School District, et al., Petitioners v. Cathy
Kuhlmeier, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
join.
No. 86-6867. Leslie Lowenfield, Petitioner v. C. Paul Phelps, Secre-
tary, Louisiana Department of Corrections, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Justice Stevens joins in Part III
of this opinion, except for the last sentence. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins and Justice Stevens
joins as to Part I.
No. 86-1415. Evelyn Marino, et al., Petitioners v. Juan U. Ortiz, et
al.; and Wayne Costello, et al., Petitioners v. New York City Police De-
partment, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. The judgment of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit in the case of Marino v. Ortiz is af-
firmed by an equally divided Court and the judgment of the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in the case of Costello v.
New York City Police Department is affirmed. Opinion per curiam an-
nounced by the Chief Justice.
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 86-1672. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Jesse
C. Bollinger, et al. Argued by Mr. Alan I. Horowitz for the petitioner
and by Mr. Charles R. Hembree for the respondents.

WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1988

appellee.
No. 86-1696. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Peti-
tioner v. Commercial Office Products Company. Argued by Mr. Rich-
ard J. Lazarus for the petitioner and by Mr. James L. Stone for the
respondent.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-532. Terrence K., Applicant v. United States Department of
State, et al. The application for stay presented to Justice Blackmun and
by him referred to the Court is denied. The order entered January 9,
1988 is vacated.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1988
309
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-919. The Times Mirror Company, et al., Appellants v. City
of Los Angeles. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-871. Potomac Electric Power Company, Petitioner v. J. Jo-
seph Curran, Jr., Attorney General of Maryland, et al. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Deakins v. Monaghan, 484 U. S. — (1988) and to consider the ques-
tion of mootness.
No. 86-2015. General Electric Company, Petitioner v. United
States, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Westfall v. Erwin, 484 U. S. (1988).
No. 86-6678. John H. Plath, Petitioner v. South Carolina. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Common Pleas of South Caro-
lina, Beaufort County. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Common.
Pleas of South Carolina, Beaufort County, for further consideration in
light of Yates v. Aiken, 484 U. S. ——— (1988).
No. 86-6698. John D. Arnold, Petitioner v. South Carolina. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Common Pleas of South Caro-

310
TUESDAY, JANUARY 19. 1988
lina, Beaufort County. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Com-
mon Pleas of South Carolina, Beaufort County, for further consider-
ation in light of Yates v. Aiken, 484 U. S. — (1988).
-
No. 87-275. Gerald M. Sparks, Petitioner v. Character and Fitness
Committee of Kentucky, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case
is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Forrester v. White, 484 U. S.
(1988).
No. 87–299. Donna Crooks and Brenda Holmes, Petitioners v. John
H. Maynard, Judge. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Forrester v. White, 484 U. S.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
(1988).
No. Joseph McDonald, Petitioner v. Charles Black. The motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time,
is denied.
No. 109, Original. States of Oklahoma and Texas, Plaintiffs v. State
of New Mexico. It is ordered that Jerome C. Muys, Esquire, of Wash-
ington, D.C., be appointed Special Master in this case with authority to
fix the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to
direct subsequent proceeding, and the authority to summon witnesses,
issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such
as he may deem necessary to call for. The Master is directed to submit
such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Master, the allowances to him, the com-
pensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical assist-
ants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses, in-
cluding travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
No. 85-1765. Bankers Life and Casualty Company, Appellant v.
Lloyd M. Crenshaw. The motion of appellant for leave to file a supple-
mental brief after argument is granted. Justice Stevens took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1988
311
No. 86-1836. New York State Club Association, Inc., Appellant v.
City of New York, et al. The motion of Licensing Board of the City
of Boston for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 87-59. United States Postal Service, Petitioner v. National As-
sociation of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO. The motion of the Solicitor
General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 87-157. Allied Tube & Conduit Corporation, Petitioner v. In-
dian Head, Inc. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
denied.
No. 87-354. Arizona, Petitioner v. Ronald William Roberson. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Robert L. Barrasso, Esquire, of Tucson, Arizona, is appointed to serve
as counsel for the respondent in this case. The motion of petitioner to
dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 87-660. Karen D. Peters, et al., Petitioners v. City of Shreve-
port. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 87–1001. H. K. Porter Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Metropoli-
tan Dade County, Florida, and John A. Dyer, etc. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 87-5269. James R. Ohse, Petitioner v. Michael Hughes, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Petitioner is allowed until February 9, 1988, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a
writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
No. 87-5875. Peter Norwood Popham, Petitioner v. City of Kenne-
saw, etc., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until February 9, 1988, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules
of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1988
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 87-920. Natalie Meyer, Colorado Secretary of State and Duane
Woodard, Colorado Attorney General, Appellants v. Paul K. Grant, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-626. Michael N. Sheridan, et ux., Petitioners v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.
No. 87-573. United States, Petitioner v. Larry Lee Taylor. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 87-5428. Prentiss Houston, Petitioner, v. Larry Lack, Warden.

Circuit granted.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 86-1357. United States Department of Justice, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Kenneth Michael Julian and Margaret J. Wallace. Argued
by Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler for the petitioners and by Mr. Eric Robert
Glitzenstein for the respondents.
No. 86-1172. Goodyear Atomic Corporation, Appellant v. Esto
Miller and Industrial Commission of Ohio. Argued by Mr. Robert E.
Tait for the appellant, by Mr. Thomas W. Merrill for the United States,
as amicus curiae, supporting appellant, by special leave of Court, and
by Mr. Stewart R. Jaffy for the appellee.
No. 85-1910. Business Electronics Corporation, Petitioner v. Sharp
Electronics Corporation. Argued by Mr. Gary V. McGowan for the
petitioner and by Mr. Harold R. Tyler, Jr., for the respondent.
No. 86-5309. Bobby Lynn Ross, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. Argued by
Mr. Gary Peterson for the petitioner and by Mr. Robert A. Nance for
the respondent.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1988
327
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor
and Justice Scalia.
OPINIONS
No. 86-1602. United Savings Association of Texas, Petitioner v.
Timbers of Inwood Forest Associates, Ltd. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 86-1021. Carnegie-Mellon University, et al., Petitioners v. Mau-
rice B. Cohill, Jr., Judge, United States District Court for the Western
District of Pennsylvania, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Order affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join.
No. 86-728. Bill Honig, California Superintendent of Public Instruc-
tion, Petitioner v. John Doe and Jack Smith. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed in part as modified by the opinion of the Court and judgment
affirmed in part by an equally divided Court. Opinion by Justice Bren-
nan. Concurring opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Scalia with whom Justice O'Connor joins.

MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
329
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-661. Northwood Nursing and Convalescent Home, Inc.,
Appellant v. City of Philadelphia Board of Revision of Taxes. Appeal
from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania. The motion of appellee
for damages is denied. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly
presented federal question.
No. 87-871. Ernest A. Hunter, Appellant v. Edward M. Murray,
Judge, Court of Claims, Albany, New York, et al. Appeal from the
Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judicial
Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5919. Stanley March, Appellant v. Catherine Ann March.
Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-5926. James Riley Lemons, Appellant v. J. R. Driskill,
Assistant Warden, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5974. Howard L. Robertson, III, Appellant v. Deborah F.
Jones, aka Deborah Robertson. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Delaware. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-904. Americana Corporation, Appellant v. State Highway
and Transportation Commissioner of Virginia. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
properly presented federal question.

330
MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
No. 87-927. Rupert Richardson, et al., Appellants v. Edwin W.
Edwards, Governor of Louisiana, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Middle District of Lousiana. The judgment is
affirmed.
No. 87-5659. John E. Tischio, Appellant v. New Jersey. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 87-5988. Joel S. Flakes, Appellant v. Wisconsin. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District I. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.

disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application for stay

332
MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
of execution of sentence of death, presented to Justice Stevens and by
him referred to the Court, is granted pending the disposition by this
Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall
continue pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
343
No. 87-343. Montana, et al., Appellants v. Crow Tribe of Indians,
et al. The application of appellees to issue the judgment forthwith pre-
sented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is granted.
OPINIONS
No. 86-595. United States, Petitioner v. Joseph A. Fausto. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall join.
No. 86-1034. Virginia, Appellant v. American Booksellers Associa-
tion Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Questions certified to the Supreme Court of Virginia.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
part and dissenting in part.
No. 86-5963. Ray Taylor, Petitioner v. Illinois. On writ of certiorari
to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Stevens announced by the Chief Justice. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice
Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.



(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1988
345
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-6196. John S. Gardner, Jr., Petitioner v. North Carolina. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to the
Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution of
sentence of death.



(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1988
347
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-6360. Raymond Robert Clark, Petitioner v. Richard L.
Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Stevens and by him referred to the Court is granted pending
the disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari.
Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay termi-
nates automatically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is
granted, this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judg-
ment of this Court. Justice White would deny the application for stay.
Justice Scalia took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.



(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1988
349
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-6406. Calvin Joseph Williams, Petitioner v. James A.
Lynaugh, Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by
this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall con-
tinue pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court. Justice
White took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.



(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1988
351
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, and Justice
Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"This special sitting of the Court is held today to receive the commis-
sion of the newly appointed Associate Justice of the United States, An-
thony M. Kennedy. The Court now recognizes the Attorney General of
the United States. Mr. Meese."
The Attorney General said:
"Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court, I have the commis-
sion which has been issued to the Honorable Anthony M. Kennedy as an
Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. The com-
mission has been duly signed by the President of the United States and
attested by me as the Attorney General of the United States. I move
that the Clerk read the commission and that it be made part of the per-
manent records of this Court."
The Chief Justice said:
"Thank you Mr. Attorney General; your motion is granted. Mr.
Clerk, will you please read the commission?"
The Clerk then reads the commission as follows:
"Ronald Reagan, President of the United States of America,
"To All Who Shall See These Presents, Greeting:
"Know Ye; That reposing special trust and confidence in the Wisdom,
Uprightness, and Learning of Anthony M. Kennedy, of California, I
have nominated, and, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate,
do appoint him as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United
States and do authorize and empower him to execute and fulfill the
duties of that Office according to the Constitution and Laws of the said
United States, and to Have and to Hold the said Office, with all the
powers, privileges and emoluments to the same of right appertaining,
unto Him, the said Anthony M. Kennedy, during his good behavior.
"In testimony whereof, I have caused these Letters to be made pat-
ent and the seal of the Department of Justice to be hereunto affixed.
"Done at the City of Washington, this eleventh day of February, in
the year of our Lord one thousand nine hundred and eighty-eight, and
of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred
and twelfth.

352
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1988
"By the President: Ronald Reagan.
"Edwin Meese, III, Attorney General." (SEAL)
The Chief Justice said:
"I now ask the Deputy Marshal of the Court to escort Judge Kennedy
to the center of the bench."
The Chief Justice said:
"Judge Kennedy, are you prepared to take the oath?"
Judge Kennedy said:
"I am."
"I, Anthony M. Kennedy, do solemnly swear that I will administer
justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and to
the rich, and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform
all the duties incumbent upon me as Associate Justice of the Supreme
Court of the United States according to the best of my abilities and un-
derstanding, agreeably to the Constitution and laws of the United
States; that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United
States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true
faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, with-
out any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well
and faithfully discharge the duties of the office of which I am about to
enter. So help me God."
Anthony M. Kennedy
"Subscribed and sworn to before me this eighteenth day of February,
1988."
William H. Rehnquist
Chief Justice
The Chief Justice said:
"Justice Kennedy, on behalf of all the members of the Court, it is a
pleasure to extend to you a very warm welcome as an Associate Justice
of this Court and to wish for you a very long life and a long and happy
career in our common calling."
ORDER
It is ordered that the following allotment be made of the Chief Justice
and Associate Justices of this Court among the circuits, pursuant to
Title 28, United States Code, Section 42 and that such allotment be
entered of record, effective February 18, 1988, viz:
For the District of Columbia Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Chief
Justice,

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1988
353
For the First Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate Justice,
For the Second Circuit, Thurgood Marshall, Associate Justice,
For the Third Circuit, William J. Brennan, Jr., Associate Justice,
For the Fourth Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Chief Justice,
For the Fifth Circuit, Byron R. White, Associate Justice,
For the Sixth Circuit, Antonin Scalia, Associate Justice,
For the Seventh Circuit, John Paul Stevens, Associate Justice,
For the Eighth Circuit, Harry A. Blackmun, Associate Justice,
For the Ninth Circuit, Sandra Day O'Connor, Associate Justice,
For the Tenth Circuit, Byron R. White, Associate Justice,
For the Eleventh Circuit, Anthony M. Kennedy, Associate Justice,
For the Federal Circuit, William H. Rehnquist, Chief Justice.
Adjourned to the time and place appointed by law.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1988
355
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-820. Edna S. Kellam, Kathryn L. Kellam and James L.
Kellam, Appellants v. James P. Pfeifer, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a properly presented federal question.
No. 87-918. Steven K. Smith, etc., Appellant v. Florida Department
of Business Regulation, Division of Land Sales, Condominiums and Mo-
bile Homes. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, First.
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 87-1016. Eddie Gerry Story, aka Gradus E. Story, Appellant v.
California. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 87-1027. Frank Ronald Rester, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87–1035. James P. Joyce, Jr., Appellant v. Lewis Bolt & Nut
Company, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87–1060. Lynda Cassidy Taylor Logemann, etc., Appellant v.
Robert F. Craig, etc, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ne-
braska. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 87-1081. Grand Forks-Traill Water Users, Inc., Appellant v.
Walter R. Hjelle, North Dakota State Highway Commissioner. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of North Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-6064. Gladys I. Seaborne, Appellant v. County Commission-
ers of Washington County. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of

356
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1988
Maine. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 87-946. City of Palo Alto, et al., Appellants v. Century Federal,
Inc., and United States. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of California. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction.
No. 87-1003. Michael Schaefer, Appellant v. State Administrative
Board of Election Laws. Appeal from the Court of Special Appeals of
Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 87–1071. Bryon T. Liggett, et ux., Appellants v. State Farm
Fire and Casualty Company. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1096. Robert F. Wright, et al., etc., Appellants v. Alfred L.
Welch, III, et al., etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Massachu-
setts. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1123. Carol Tuttle Christian, et al., Appellants v. E. Garrett
Bewkes. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-1162. Alice Clissuras, Appellant v. City of New York, et al.
Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, Sec-
ond Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-5419. Harold Koss, Appellant v. David Slater, Judge. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a pe-
tition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6095. Levi Martinez, Appellant v. Colorado. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
357
No. 87-544. Philip Coombe, Superintendent, Eastern Correctional
Facility, Petitioner v. Robert Escalera. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit for further consideration in light of Taylor v. Illinois,
484 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-5836. Bernard Kenneth Biddle, Jr., Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
. Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of the position presently asserted by the Solicitor
General in his brief filed January 11, 1988.

No. 87-5954. Lee V. Langster, Petitioner v. Department of Health
and Human Services. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until March 14, 1988,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting:
For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6067. Michael Flaherty, Petitioner v. United States. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Peti-
tioner is allowed until March 14, 1988, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ
of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would

360
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1988
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6219. Jose A. Perez, et ux, Petitioners v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until March 14, 1988, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ
of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons ex-
pressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would
deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of
the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

nois. In these cases probable jurisdiction is noted. The cases are con-
solidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. In this case proba-

No. 87-1279. Alexia Morrison, Independent Counsel, Appellant v.
Theodore B. Olson, Edward C. Schmults and Carol E. Dinkins. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. The motion of Law-
rence Walsh, Independent Counsel, for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted. The motions to establish an expedited schedule for
briefing and oral argument are granted. Appellant's brief shall be filed
by 3 p.m. March 9, 1988. Appellees' briefs shall be filed by 3 p.m. April
8, 1988. Reply briefs, if any, shall be filed by 3 p.m. April 18, 1988. Oral
argument is set for April 26, 1988 at 10 a.m. The motion to dispense
temporarily with printing briefs is denied. The motions for additional
time for oral argument are denied without prejudice. The application
for full stay of mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit presented to the Chief Justice and by him

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1988
361
referred to the Court is granted pending the sending down of the judg-
ment of this Court. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or
decision of these motions and orders.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1988
399
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-877. United States, Petitioner v. James Joseph Owens. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with
whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Kennedy took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-2079. Laborers Health and Welfare Trust Fund, for North-
ern California, et al., Petitioners v. Advanced Lightweight Concrete
Co., Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Jus-
tice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1552. Department of the Navy, Petitioner v. Thomas E.
Egan. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice White with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Jus-
tice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-870. Phillips Petroleum Company and Cinque Bambini Part-
nership, Petitioners v. Mississippi and Saga Petroleum U.S., Inc. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Scalia join. Justice Kennedy
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-939. ETSI Pipeline Project, Petitioner v. Missouri, et al.; and
No. 86-941. Donald P. Hodel, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Missouri, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice White. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases.

400
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1988

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1988
401
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-1430. R. "Roy" Peralta, Appellant v. Heights Medical Cen-
ter, Inc., dba Heights Hospital, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of Texas, First District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Justice Kennedy took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1146. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner v. Mary Alice Galbreath. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Brennan. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision.
of this case.
No. 86-753. Richard Pennell and Tri-County Apartment House Own-
ers Association, Appellants v. City of San Jose and City Council of San
Jose. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Scalia concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice O'Connor joins.
Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 86-937. United States, Petitioner v. Thomas O. Robinson, Jr. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring
in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall
with whom Justice Brennan joins. Justice Kennedy took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1278. Hustler Magazine and Larry C. Flynt, Petitioners v.
Jerry Falwell. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the

402
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1988
opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice
White concurring in the judgment. Justice Kennedy took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-6109. Frederick Mathews, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice
White with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Justice Kennedy took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 29, 1988
403
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens,
Justice O'Connor, and Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-747. Paul Duffy, et ux., Appellants v. City of Arcadia. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1179. Russell T. Weil, et al., etc., Petitioners v. Roderick
G.W. Chu, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1133. First Federal Savings and Loan Association of
Claremore, Oklahoma and Great Plains Federal Savings and Loan
Association of Weatherford, Oklahoma, Appellants v. Oklahoma Tax
Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oklahoma. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 87-1145. David A. Potter, Appellant v. The Wackenhut Corpora-
tion, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1148. Robert E. Norton, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6258. David L. Howard, Appellant v. Viacom International,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-5269. James R. Ohse, Petitioner v. Michael Hughes, et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

404
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 29, 1988
the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Forrester v. White, 484 U.S. (1988).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 103, Original. South Dakota, Plaintiff v. States of Nebraska,
Iowa and Missouri. The pending motion for leave to file a bill of
complaint is denied without prejudice to renewal of the motion.
No. 86-1294. William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence,
Petitioner v. John Doe. The motion of respondent for leave to file a
supplemental brief after argument is granted. Justice Kennedy took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 87-573. United States, Petitioner v. Larry Lee Taylor. The mo-
tion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Ian G.
Loveseth, Esquire, of San Francisco, California, is appointed to serve
as counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 87-1068. Oklahoma Tax Commission, Petitioner v. Muscogee
(Creek) Nation, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 87–1080. Maryland National Bank, Appellant v. Maryland State
Department of Assessments and Taxation. The Solicitor General is in-
vited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this order.
No. 87-1279. Alexia Morrison, Independent Counsel, Appellant v.
Theodore B. Olson, Edward C. Schmults and Carol E. Dinkins. The
motion of Whitney North Seymour, Jr., Independent Counsel, for leave
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Justice Kennedy took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 87-5277. Tony B. Amadeo, Petitioner v. Ralph Kemp, Warden.
The motion of petitioner for an extension of time to file a reply brief is
denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 87–746. Michael H. and Victoria D., Appellants v. Gerald D. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District.
In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1988
421
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-1128. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Assibi Abudu. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of Loui-
siana, et al. (Alabama and Mississippi Boundary case). On Exceptions
to the Report of the Special Master. The Exceptions of Mississippi to
the Supplement Report of the Special Master overruled. The Supple-
mental Report of the Special Master and his recommendations, to the
extent they are consistent with this opinion, adopted and confirmed.
Parties directed to submit to Special Master proposed decree. Each
party shall bear its own costs. Actual expenses of the Special Master
shall be borne one-half by the United States and one-half by Missis-
sippi. Court retains jurisdiction to entertain further proceedings, enter
such orders, and issue such writs as from time to time may be deter-
mined to be necessary or advisable to effectuate and supplement the
forthcoming decree and to determine the rights of the respective par-
ties. Leave is granted parties to file, without further motion, complaint
within 60 days setting forth claims to portion of Shandeleur Sound. Op-
posing party shall have 45 days to respond. Opinion by Justice Black-
mun. Justice Marshall and Justice Kennedy took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this litigation.

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1988
423
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-772. City of St. Louis, Petitioner v. James H. Praprotnik. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Justice O'Connor announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice White and Justice Scalia
join. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall and Justice Blackmun join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 86-1650. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Independent
Federation of Flight Attendants. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed by
an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief
Justice. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.

MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1988
425
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-317. Bemis Pentecostal Church, et al., Appellants v. Tennes-
see, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Di-
vision. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-1008. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Aliakbar Fazelihokmabad. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Immigration and Naturalization
Service v. Abudu, 485 U.S. (1988).
No. 86-1049. City of Little Rock, Arkansas, Petitioner v. Debbie
Williams. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of City of St. Louis v. Praprotnik, 485 U.S.
(1988).
No. 87-852. Union Oil Company of California, Petitioner v. Sierra
Club. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Gwaltney of Smithfield v. Chesapeake Bay Founda-
tion, Inc., 484 U.S. - (1987).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Harry R. Murray, Petitioner v. United States. The motion.
to direct the Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari from the
Judicial Council for the Ninth Circuit is denied.

426
MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1988
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. James A.
Baker, III, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. The motion
for clarification of the order entered December 7, 1987 is granted. One-
half of the total fee application filed November 4, 1987 is to be paid by
the United States. One-fourth of the total fee application is to be paid
by the State of South Carolina. One-fourth of the total fee application is
to be paid by the National Governors' Association.
No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
The joint motion for approval of expenses incurred by Special Master
Wade H. McCree, Jr., deceased, is granted and the allocation set forth
in the motion is approved.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The motion of Basin Electric to file a response to plain-
tiff's motion to amend petition is granted. The motion of plaintiff to
amend petition for an order enforcing decree and for injunctive relief is
denied.
No. 86-492. Delbert Boyle, Personal Representative of the heirs and
Estate of David A. Boyle, Deceased, Petitioner v. United Technologies
Corporation. The parties may file supplemental briefs on reargument,
provided the briefs do not exceed 20 pages. Amici curiae may file sup-
plemental briefs on reargument, provided the briefs do not exceed 10
pages. Such briefs shall be served and filed on or before close of busi-
ness Wednesday, April 13, 1988.
No. 86-2037. Paul G. Landers, Petitioner v. National Railroad Pas-
senger Corporation, et al. The motion of respondents to reconsider
order denying motion for divided argument is denied.
No. 87-578. The Bank of Nova Scotia, Petitioner v. United States;
and
No. 87-602. William A. Kilpatrick, et al., Petitioners v. United
States. The motion of petitioners for leave to file portion of joint appen-
dix under seal is granted.

motion of Committee on Civil Rights of the Association of the Bar of the
City of New York for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 87-6248. Mayretta Wilson-Thomas, Petitioner v. Small Business
Administration. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until March 28, 1988, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a

MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1988
427
petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules
of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens,
dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc.,
464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.

chusetts denied. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.
No. 87-894. Arnold H. Slyper, et al., Petitioners v. Edwin Meese,
III, Attorney General, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White.

No. 87-975. Gene A. Scroggy, et al., Petitioners v. Daniel C. Sum-

is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Justice White would grant
certiorari.

Cross, Petitioners v. William M. Bennett, et al. The motion of National
Railway Labor Conference for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Justice Stevens and Justice Ken-
nedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and this
petition.

petition.

to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District, denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1988

Circuit is denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice

Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 87-6256. Linda Erickson and Marilyn Hogan, Petitioners v.
Alltech Associates, Inc. The motion of petitioner Hogan for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner Hogan is allowed until
March 28, 1988, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule
45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall
and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis. The petition for a writ of certiorari as to petitioner
Erickson is denied.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 87-5888. In Re Michael Roland Roy, Petitioner. The petition for
writ of habeas corpus is denied.

OPINIONS
No. 86–279. Basic Incorporated, et al., Petitioners v. Max L.
Levinson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackman. Opinion by Justice White
concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice O'Connor
joins. The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-751. Arkansas Best Corporation, Petitioner v. Commissioner
of Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Marshall. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 86-958. Norwest Bank Worthington, et al., Petitioners v. James
R. Ahlers, et ux. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-495. K Mart Corporation, Petitioner v. Cartier, Inc., et al.;
No. 86-624. 47th Street Photo, Inc., Petitioner v. Coalition to Pre-
serve the Integrity of American Trademarks, et al.; and
No. 86-625. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Coalition to Pre-
serve the Integrity of American Trademarks, et al. On writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Circuit. Judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit's conclusion that the United States District
Court for the District of Columbia had jurisdiction is affirmed. The case
is restored to the calendar for reargument on the merits. Opinion by
Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join. Justice Kennedy took no part
in the consideration or decision of these cases.

the petition for a writ of certiorari in Darden v. Dugger, U.S.
