(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1988
451
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 86-987. Alexander Haig, et al., Petitioners v. Gladys Bissonette,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Because the Court lacks a quorum, 28 U.S.C. Section 1,
and since a majority of the Justices are of the opinion that the case can-
not be heard and determined at the next Term of the Court, the judg-
ment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit is
affirmed under 28 U.S.C. Section 2109, which provides that under
these circumstances the Court shall enter its order affirming the judg-
ment of the court from which the case was brought for review with the
same effect as upon affirmance by an equally divided Court. The Chief
Justice, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy took no
part in this decision.
No. 87–133. Mercilyn Buchanan, etc., Petitioner v. Stanships, Inc.,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. Judgment reversed and the case is remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87–1074. First Union National Bank of Florida, et al., Appellants
v. Florida Department of Revenue, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction
and set the case for oral argument.
No. 87-1120. Poudre Valley Rural Electric Association, Inc., Appel-
lant v. City of Greeley, Colorado and Home Light and Power Company.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a properly presented federal question.

452
MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1988
No. 87-1173. Adirondack Chair Co., Inc., Appellant v. Commissioner
of Finance of the City of New York. Appeal from the Appellate Divi-
sion, Supreme Court of New York, First Judicial Department. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1174. Sterling Bancorp, Appellant v. New York City Depart-
ment of Finance and Philip R. Michael, Commissioner of Finance.
Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York,
First Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 87-1195. James Malcolm Williams, Appellant v. Lawyers Profes-
sional Responsibility Board of Minnesota. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 87-1275. Replan Development, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Department of Housing Preservation and Development of the City of
New York, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1367. John Emil Bomhardt, Appellant v. Maryland; and John
Emil Bomhardt, Appellant v. Maryland. Appeal from the Court of
Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 87–1266. James R. Bell, Appellant v. Margaret Ann Bell. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Sixth Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-1320. Jean Rosenbaum, Appellant v. Kurt Rosenbaum.
Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6227. Lyle H. Prenzler, Appellant v. Ann McLaughlin, Secre-
tary of Labor. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6259. Ahsan Mohiuddin, Appellant v. California. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1988
453
No. 87-6285. Mary B. Edwards, et al., Appellants v. Walter C.
Fisher, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-1503. Marco Samayoa, et al., Petitioners v. Chicago Board of
Education, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit to con-
sider the question of mootness.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Application of Theodore C. Hirt for Admission to the Bar of
This Court. The application of Theodore Hirt for admission to the Bar
of this Court presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the
Court is granted. Justice Blackmun would deny the application.

No. 87-6320. Donald Francis MacKay, Jr., Petitioner v. Mercedes
Benz of North America, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until April
11, 1988, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a)
and to submit a petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed
in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the
petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the
motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6491. Joseph J. Pavlico, Petitioner v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the
Court is denied.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-1672. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Jesse
C. Bollinger, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Scalia. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 86-803. Michael Boos, J. Michael Waller and Bridget Brooker,
Petitioners v. Marion S. Barry, Jr., Mayor, District of Columbia, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed in part, affirmed in part,
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Justice O'Connor delivered
the opinion of the Court except as to Part II-A. Opinion by Justice
Brennan concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom
Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in part
and dissenting in part with whom Justice White and Justice Blackmun
join. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 86-986. Eric J. Schneidewind, et al., Petitioners v. ANR Pipe-
line Company and ANR Storage Company. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Kennedy took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1329. Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, Petitioner v.
Mayacamas Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Justice Ken-
nedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

No. 86-1471. Richard A. Lyng, Secretary of Agriculture, Appellant
v. International Union, United Automobile Aerospace and Agricultural
Implement Workers of America, UAW, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Columbia. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the District Court for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan and
Justice Blackmun join. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 86-1521. United States, Appellant v. Wells Fargo Bank, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central District of
California. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the District Court
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Justice Kennedy took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-863. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner v. Kenneth Kizer, Director of California Department of
Health Services, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals with instructions to dismiss the suit. See
Deakins v. Monaghan, 484 U.S.
(1988); United States
v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36, 39-40 (1950). Opinion per curiam
announced by the Chief Justice. Justice Kennedy took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1988
485
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of New Mexico for leave to file a reply brief is granted. New
Mexico's Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master are overruled.
The Report of the Special Master is approved and amended decree
entered. United States dismissed from this proceeding without preju-
dice. The Court retains jurisdiction of this suit. Opinion per curiam.
Neil S. Grigg, of Fort Collins, Colorado, is appointed River Master of
the Pecos River. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1298. Walter J. Beppler, Appellant v. Township of Washing-
ton, et al. Appeal from the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate
Division. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6407. Frederick Lee Danielson, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal
from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86–1151. Gary R. Frink and Sherry R. Frink, Petitioners v.
Commissioner of Internal Revenue. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Commissioner of Internal Revenue
v. Bollinger, 485 U.S. (1988).

486
MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1988
No. 86-1152. James M. George and Margaret C. George, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Commissioner of
Internal Revenue v. Bollinger, 485 U.S. (1988).

should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court..

disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 87-6343. Laura J. Henslee, Petitioner v. William Sykes, etc. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until April 18, 1988, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ
of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6382. Henry Warren Randolph, Petitioner v. James A.
Lynaugh, Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner

488
MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1988
is allowed until April 18, 1988, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ of certiorari in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6397. Rector L. Guinn, Petitioner v. June A. Guinn. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until April 18, 1988, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ
of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens,
dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-6700. John Henry Selvage, Petitioner v. James A. Lynaugh,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for stay of
execution of sentence of death, presented to Justice White and by him
referred to the Court, is granted pending the disposition by this Court
of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of
certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event
the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue
pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court. The Chief
Justice, Justice White, and Justice O'Connor would deny the applica-
tion for stay and the petition for a writ of certiorari.

APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-609. Shell Oil Company, Appellant v. Director of Revenue of
Missouri. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1212. Jerome Greene, et al., Appellants v. Manuel Mirabel,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, First Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 87–1345. Jon G. Leavelle, Appellant v. California. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-1357. Thomas R. Angel, et ux., Appellants v. Charles W.
Froehlich, Jr., Judge, San Diego North County Superior Court, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-6417. Kenneth Dean Reiszner, Appellant v. Mila Jane
Burnett Reiszner. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-1471. Clarence Willard Franklin, Appellant v. Office of
Personnel Management. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Federal Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice Brennan, Justice

506
MONDAY, APRIL 4, 1988
Blackmun, Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia would affirm the
judgment.
No. 87-6438. David L. Manter, Appellant v. Town of Fayette,
Maine. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a properly presented federal question.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Paul G. Evans, Petitioner v. United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition
for writ of certiorari that does not comply with the Rules of this Court
is denied.
No. D-691. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Glenn
Newhouse. It is ordered that Richard Glenn Newhouse, of Fort
Lauderdale, Florida, be suspended from the practice of law in this
Court and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him
to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law
in this Court.
No. D-692. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph Kalk. It is
ordered that Joseph Kalk, of Beachwood, Ohio, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-693. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald Laurence
Goldman. It is ordered that Ronald Laurence Goldman, of Marina Del
Rey, California, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.

is ordered that Moreland G. Smith, Jr., of Dallas, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

motion of Lawrence E. Walsh, Independent Counsel for leave to par-
ticipate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument and
for additional time for oral argument is denied. The motion of of Michael
K. Deaver for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae,
for divided argument and for additional time for oral argument is
denied. The joint motion for additional time for oral argument, for
divided argument and for amici curiae to participate in oral argument
is granted in part and denied in part. An additional thirty minutes is
allotted for oral argument to be divided as follows: appellant -30 min-
utes; the United States Senate, as amicus curiae-15 minutes; one
counsel for appellees-30 minutes; and the Solicitor General, as amicus
curiae 15 minutes. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration
or decision of these motions.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,

No. 87-6780. Leslie Lowenfield, Petitioner v. Robert Hilton Butler,
Warden. The application for stay of execution of the sentence of death
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is denied.

joins. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the applica-
tion for stay.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1988
529
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87–1366. Andrew T. Dubish, Appellant v. Kansas. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Kansas. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1400. Alberto Clausell, et ux., Appellants v. Hobart Corpora-
tion. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87–1457. D. K. Hurley and Eunice Justice, Appellants v. West
American Insurance Co. of Ohio Casualty Group and Ohio Casualty In-
surance Company. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6485. Graydon Roger Boles, Appellant v. T. E. Ellis, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle District of
North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87–1392. First American National Bank of Knoxville, Appellant
v. Dudley Taylor, Commissioner of Revenue for the State of Tennessee.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Eastern Division. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 87-1435. Bill Oliver Blume, Appellant v. Marvin D. Gregersen,
Chief, Bureau of Occupational Licenses, Department of Self-Governing
Agencies of Idaho, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Idaho.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

530
MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1988
No. 87-6444. Paul Nunley, Appellant v. Oklahoma. Appeal from the
Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Clarence Eisen, Petitioner v. Sackman-Gilliland Corp. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari, out-of-
time, is denied.
No. A-738. Michael Rapp, Applicant v. United States. The applica-
tion for bail addressed to Justice White and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. A-788. Alcee L. Hastings, Judge, United States District Court

No. D-674. In the Matter of Disbarment of Nicholas George
Dozoryst, II. Nicholas George Dozoryst, II, of Chicago, Illinois, having
requested to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered.
that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice
before the Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore is-
sued on January 25, 1988, is hereby discharged.
No. D-693. In the Matter of Ronald Laurence Goldman. Due to mis-
taken identity, the order entered April 4, 1988, suspending Ronald
Laurence Goldman, of Marina Del Rey, California, from the practice of
law in this Court is vacated and the Rule to Show Cause issued on that
date is discharged.

ordered that Richard J. Hopkins, of Silver Spring, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1988
No. 87–1160. Duquesne Light Company and Pennsylvania Power

ages is denied.
No. 87-6325. Donald Ray Perry, Petitioner v. William D. Leeke,
Commissioner, South Carolina Department of Corrections, et al. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that W.
Gaston Fairey, Esquire, of Columbia, South Carolina, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 87-6453. Arthur N. Economou, et ux., Petitioners v. Securities
and Exchange Commission. The motion of petitioners for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioners are allowed until May 9,
1988, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and
to submit a petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33
of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun and Justice Scalia, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion
to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6459. Richard Rydell, Petitioner v. City of Atlantic City,
New Jersey. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 9, 1988, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules
of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens,
dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc.,
464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6489. William Howard, Petitioner v. City of Fort Myers,
Florida, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 9, 1988, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules.
of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens,
dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

Appeals―JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
533
No. 87-1269. March Fong Eu, Secretary of State of California, et al.,
Appellants v. San Francisco County Democratic Central Committee, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. The Chief Justice took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 87-1327. Cotton Petroleum Corporation, et al., Appellants v.
New Mexico, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. The parties are invited also
to brief and argue the following question: "Does the Commerce Clause
require that an Indian Tribe be treated as a state for purposes of deter-
mining whether a state tax on nontribal activities conducted on an In-
dian Reservation must be apportioned to account for taxes imposed on
those same activities by the Indian Tribe?"
No. 87-5840. Edward McNamara, Appellant v. County of San Diego
Department of Social Services. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, Fourth Appellate District. Further consideration of the question
of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the case on the merits.

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied.
No. 87-6620. Juan Hernandez-Beltran, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit denied.

Janklow, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied.

MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1988
543
No. 87-6666. Anthony M. Laurenco, Petitioner v. Otis R. Bowen,
Secretary of Health and Human Services. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 87-6780. Leslie Lowenfield, Petitioner v. Robert Hilton Butler,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.
No. 87–1187. Alcee L. Hastings, Judge, United States District Court
for the Southern District of Florida, Petitioner v. Judicial Conference of
the United States, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied.
The Chief Justice took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 87-1221. Mississippi, Petitioner v. Mark Anthony Parker. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi
denied.
No. 87-1234. Richard L. Dugger, Secretary, Florida Department of
Corrections, Petitioner v. William Duane Elledge. The motion of Wil-
liam Duane Elledge to direct the Clerk to file cross-petition for a writ of
certiorari, out of-time, is denied. The motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.
No. 87-1401. Cargill, Incorporated, Petitioner v. Charter Interna-
tional Oil Company. The motion of petitioner for leave to submit Rule
28.1 material under seal is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied. Justice
Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion
and this petition.
No. 87-1484. International Association of Machinists & Aerospace
Workers, Lodge 751, Petitioner v. Boeing Company, et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit denied. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this petition.
No. 87-6254. Ignacio Cuevas, Petitioner v. Texas. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 87-6487. Stephen Todd Booker, Petitioner v. Richard L. Dug-
ger, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh

544

Circuit denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall.

to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

habeas corpus is denied.

writ of mandamus is denied.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Pow-
ell (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit during the period of June 6 through
June 10, 1988, and for such further time as may be required to complete
unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 294(a), is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 295.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, APRIL 19, 1988
557
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-1406. Puerto Rico Department of Consumer Affairs, et al.,
Petitioners v. Isla Petroleum Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals of the United States.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Temporary Emergency
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Justice O'Connor took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1961. Tulsa Professional Collection Services, Inc., Appellant
v. Joanne Pope, Executrix of the Estate of H. Everett Pope, Jr., De-
ceased. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oklahoma. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Oklahoma for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Justice Blackmun concurs in the result.
Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice.
No. 86-1013. Richard E. Lyng, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Northwest Indian Cemetery Protective Association, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan
with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join. Justice Ken-
nedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-978. Sandra Gardebring, Commissioner of the Minnesota De-
partment of Human Services, Petitioner v. Kathryn Jenkins. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judg-
ment in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Brennan joins
and with whom Justice Marshall joins as to the last paragraph. Justice
Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

for the petitioners, by Mr. Brian J. Martin for the United States as

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 20, 1988
559
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-935. Regents of the University of California, Appellant v.
Public Employment Relations Board, et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, First Appellate District. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeal for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice Ken-
nedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-622. Eugene Traynor, Petitioner v. Thomas K. Turnage, Ad-
ministrator, Veterans' Administration and the Veterans' Administra-
tion. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit; and
No. 86-737. James P. McKelvey, Petitioner v. Thomas K. Turnage,
Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The judgment in No. 86-737 is affirmed. The judgment in No. 86-622 is
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice White. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases.
No. 86-1461. Edward J. DeBartolo Corp., Petitioner v. Florida Gulf
Coast Building and Construction Trades Council and National Labor
Relations Board. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
White. Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia concur in the judgment. Jus-
tice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. James A.
Baker, III, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. On Excep-
tions to the Report of the Special Master. The motion of National
Governors' Association for leave to intervene as plaintiff granted. Ex-

560
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 20, 1988
ceptions to the Report of the Special Master overruled and recommen-
dation of Special Master approved. Judgment entered for defendant.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in
part and concurring in the judgment. Concurring opinion by Justice
Stevens. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice O'Connor. Justice Kennedy took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1988
563
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 87–107. Brenda Patterson, Petitioner v. McLean Credit Union.
This case is restored to the calendar for reargument. The parties are
requested to brief and argue the following question: "Whether or not
the interpretation of 42 U.S.C. §1981 adopted by this Court in Runyon
v. McCrary, 427 U.S. 160 (1976), should be reconsidered?" Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and
Justice Blackmun join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1117. City of Manassas, Virginia, et al., Appellants v. United
States. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 87–1462. Terry Rogers, Appellant v. City of Cheyenne. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Wyoming. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1463. Charles W. Brown, Appellant v. Brown and Root
U.S.A. Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. The motion of appellant for a free white Christian
male bench is denied. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1503. William M. Shipps, Appellant v. Stoughton Police
Department, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

564
MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1988
No. 87-1539. Ronald L. Branson, Appellant v. California. Appeal
from the Appellate Department, Superior Court of California, Los An-
geles County. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6539. Fred A. Whitaker, Appellant v. T. N. Peterson, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-6544. Fred Whitaker, Appellant v. Donald Pascarella, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-1986. North Broward Hospital District, Petitioner v. Otis
R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Bethesda Hospital Association v. Bowen, 485 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-57. University of Cincinnati, dba University Hospital, Peti-
tioner v. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Bethesda Hospital Association v. Bowen, 485 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-443. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner v. Adams House Health Care, et al. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Bethesda
Hospital Association v. Bowen, 485 U.S. (1988).

from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Albert P. Pacione, Jr., of Newburgh, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Roger George Seaman, of Chicago, Illinois, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

581
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-946. Employment Division, Department of Human Resources
of the State of Oregon, et al., Petitioners v. Alfred L. Smith; and
No. 86-947. Employment Division, Department of Human Resources
of the State of Oregon, et al., Petitioners v. Galen W. Black. On writs of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Oregon. Judgments vacated and
cases remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and
Justice Blackmun join. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of these cases.
No. 86-787. Cecil Hicks, District Attorney for County of Orange,
California, Acting on Behalf of Alta Sue Feiock, Petitioner v. Phillip
William Feiock. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of Califor-
nia, Fourth Appellate District. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeal for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by
Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join.
Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 86-2037. Paul G. Landers, Petitioner v. National Railroad Pas-
senger Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice White.
No. 87-59. United States Postal Service, Petitioner v. National As-
sociation of Letter Carriers, AFL-CIO. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion
per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 2, 1988
583
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Scalia.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1526. Edward Dean Christensen, Appellant v. Utah State
Tax Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87–6568. Gregory Spellman, Appellant v. United States, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6589. Juvart T. Mingledolph, Appellant v. John McKean,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1414. Nicholas Marino, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of
Mathews v. United States, 485 U.S. (1988).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Carlton A. Hodges, Petitioner v. United States, et al. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file the petition for writ of certiorari, out-
of-time, is denied.
A-763. Modjeski & Masters, Applicant v. Jan R. Carter, et al. The
application for stay filed with Justice White and referred by him to the
Court, is hereby granted, and the temporary stay entered by Justice
White on April 15, 1988, is vacated.

584
MONDAY, MAY 2, 1988
The judgments of the Louisiana Court of Appeal for the Fourth Cir-
cuit and the Louisiana Civil District Court for the Parish of Orleans are
stayed pending the timely docketing of an appeal by appellants in the
above-entitled case. Should such an appeal be so timely docketed, this
order is to continue pending this Court's action on the jurisdictional
statement or further disposition of such appeal.
This order is conditioned upon the timely posting with the Louisiana
Civil District Court for the Parish of Orleans of a good and sufficient
bond in the amount of $700,000 plus interest from April 15, 1988, by
appellant Modjeski & Masters, covering any potential obligations under
the judgment of the Louisiana Civil District Court for the Parish of
Orleans. Unless and until Modjeski & Masters posts said bond, the stay
is expressly conditioned on appellant's taking no action to reduce its
current net worth and, in particular, not:
(A) distributing any earnings of the firm to its partners who continue
to work for the firm, except as they have been receiving hereto-
fore in salary and benefits or as provided in (B) and (D) below, or
(B) distributing any earnings of the firm to its partners for so long as
the net worth of the firm is below $700,000, or
(C) Transferring or encumbering any existing assets, funds, or ex-
isting contracts of the partnership to or on behalf of any other
parties, beyond security interests or liens already in existence,
except as is necessary in the ordinary course of its business, for
the defense or settlement or both of the pending actions against
it, or for payment to associates and employees in accordance with
existing employment contracts;
And further provided that
(D) Profits accumulated after the payment of salaries and other
expenses shall be distributed as follows:
(1) if the net worth of the firm is between $700,000 and $1.1
million, then up to 50% of accumulated profits may be distrib-
uted to the partners; the remainder will be accumulated in
the partnership,
(2) if the net worth of the firm is above $1.1 million, then all prof-
its above that amount may be distributed to the partners;
and
(E) Appellant shall furnish to appellees within 30 days of the end of
each quarter:
(1) a statement from the managing partner of Modjeski &
Masters and from its certified public accountants that all pro-
visions of this order have been complied with, and

MONDAY, MAY 2, 1988
585
(2) balance sheet and income statements for each such quarter;
and
(F) Within 120 days of the end of the calendar year, appellant shall
provide annual balance and income statements to appellees; and
(G) Appellees shall keep confidential all financial data provided
under this order: and
(H) If the net worth of Modjeski & Masters falls below $700,000,
appellees may apply to the Court for further relief; and
(I) Appellees shall have the right to select an independent auditor to
inspect any and all records of the appellant to ascertain whether
appellant is complying with the provisions of this stay.
(J) Should appellees find it necessary to seek additional relief to en-
force the terms of this order, they shall apply to the Louisiana
Civil District Court for the Parish of Orleans.
No. A-811. Michael B. Mitchell and Clarence M. Mitchell, III, Appli-
cants v. United States. The application for release pending appeal pre-
sented to Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.
No. D-706. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles M. Purvis. It
is ordered that Charles M. Purvis, of Birmingham, Alabama, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 86-1904. Arizona, Petitioner v. Larry Youngblood. The motion
of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 87-1095. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, Petitioner v. Charlie Broyles,
et al. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the
joint appendix is granted.
No. 87-1320. Jean Rosenbaum, Appellant v. Kurt Rosenbaum. The
application to suspend the effect of the order entered March 21, 1988,
addressed to Justice Scalia and referred to the Court is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-1064. United States, Petitioner v. Philip George Stuart, Sr.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by
Justice White with whom The Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 87-1274. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC,
et al., Petitioners v. Cherokee Electric Cooperative. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White.
No. 87-1341. Brown Company, et al., Petitioners v. National Labor
Relations Board. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Justice Kennedy took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 87-6593. Perry R. Ferguson, Petitioner v. Herbert Donaldson,
Judge, San Francisco Municipal Court. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 87-1342. Rodolfo T. Arambulo, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to file transcript of proceedings in the
District Court under seal is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied.
No. 87-1558. Ohio, Petitioner v. William E. Murphy. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Summit County,
denied.
No. 87-6138. Willie Mack Modden, Petitioner v. Texas. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Marshall.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 87-6618. In re David G. Harris, Petitioner. The petition for writ
of mandamus is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 87-972. William Scharrer, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 87-1237. William R. Yee, Petitioner v. B. Ward Smith, et al.;
No. 87-1334. Thomas Lee Bell and Earl Dean Jolly, Petitioners v.
United States; and
No. 87-6351. Nikolai P. Bespalchenko, Petitioner v. German Federal
Government, et al. The petitions for rehearing are denied.

OPINIONS
Carl C. Monastra
No. 85-1910. Business Electronics Corporation, Petitioner v. Sharp
Electronics Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
White joins. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 86–228. Juozas Kungys, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Justice
Scalia announced the judgment of the Court, and delivered the opinion
of the Court as to Parts I, II-A, and III-A, and an opinion joined by
the Chief Justice and Justice Brennan as to Parts II-B and III-B, and

MONDAY, MAY 2, 1988
595
by Justice O'Connor as to Part III-B. Concurring opinion by Justice
Brennan. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment with
whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion
by Justice White. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 87-65. United States, Petitioner v. Providence Journal Company
and Charles M. Hauser. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion
by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom the
Chief Justice joins. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 87-6. Guy Rufus Huddleston, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MAY 4, 1988
599
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-800. FW/PBS, Inc., dba Paris Adult Bookstore II, et al.,
Applicants v. City of Dallas, et al. The application for stay filed with
Justice White has been referred to the Court. Justice White's tempo-
rary stay is hereby vacated. The application for stay is granted and the
judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit is
stayed except for its holding that the provisions of the ordinance regu-
lating the location of sexually-oriented businesses do not violate the
Federal Constitution pending the timely filing and disposition of a peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari
be denied, this stay is to terminate automatically. In the event the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay is to continue in effect
pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 10, 1988
601
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-6927. Alexis Hamilton, as natural mother and next friend of
James Edward Smith, Petitioner v. Texas. The application for stay of
execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White and by him
referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by this Court of
the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event the
petition for writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pend-
ing the issuance of the mandate of this Court.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 16, 1988
603
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 86-1857. Continental Bank International, Appellant v. City of
New York, Department of Finance. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of New York. The motion of appellant for leave to file Rule 28.1 listing
under seal is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Justice White would note probable jurisdiction and set
the case for oral argument.
No. 87-1376. City of Euclid, Ohio, Appellant v. Richard Shank,
Director, Ohio Environmental Protection Agency. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1601. Wesley K. Bell, individually and dba Wes Outdoor Ad-
vertising Co., Appellant v. New Jersey, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1619. Thomas Green, Appellant v. Watertown Equipment
Company, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87–1441. H. Ray Evers, Appellant v. Board of Medical Examin-
ers, et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-6481. Vincent Salazar, Appellant v. Ohio Civil Rights Com-
mission, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Lucas
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.

604
MONDAY, MAY 16, 1988
No. 87-1542. Reid Ewing, Appellant v. Arizona, et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Arizona. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 87-1597. Alabama Power Company, Appellant v. Kay Capps,
Administratrix of the Estate of Richard D. Capps, deceased. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a properly presented federal question.
No. 87-1653. John R. Varney and Robert J. Hughes, Jr., Appellants
v. Florida Bar, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-7126. Alonzo Houston, Petitioner v. Alabama. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama for
further consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the
Attorney General of Alabama in his motion filed April 14, 1988. Justice
Blackmun dissents.
No. 87-1243. United States, Petitioner v. A and B Heating and Air
Conditioning, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for a writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit to con-
sider the question of mootness.
No. 87-1425. Larry E. Bay, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in light of
Mathews v. United States, 485 U.S. (1988).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Louis D. Ekin, et al., Petitioners v. Board of Commissioners
of the County of Allegheny, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file
a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
-
No. . Lewis W. Poe, Petitioner v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is
denied.

MONDAY, ΜΑΥ 16, 1988
605
No. . Leroy S. Williams, et al., Petitioners v. Washington, et al.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.
No. D-692. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph Kalk. The motion
to defer proceedings in this matter is granted.
No. D-707. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sam Blecher. It is or-
dered that Sam Blecher, of Spring Valley, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-708. In the Matter of Disbarment of Samuel H. Lewis. It is
ordered that Samuel H. Lewis, of Pompano Beach, Florida, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. James A.
Baker, III, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. The re-
quest of the Honorable Matthew J. Jasen to be discharged as Special
Master is granted and he is hereby discharged. Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 87-1428. Patricia A. Lorance, et al., Petitioners v. AT&T Tech-
nologies, Inc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 87–1495. Tallahassee Branch of the National Association for the
Advancement of Colored People, et al., Petitioners v. Leon County,
Florida, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 87-6702. Arthur Aguilar, Petitioner v. Texas. The motion of pe-
titioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is
allowed until June 6, 1988, within which to pay the docketing fee re-
quired by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ of certiorari in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting:
For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 87-6873. Arturo Aranda, Petitioner v. Texas. The application to
continue the stay of mandate of the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas,

606
MONDAY, MAY 16, 1988
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court, is granted
pending this Court's action on the petition for a writ of certiorari. If the
petition for a writ of certiorari is denied, this stay terminates automati-
cally. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this
stay shall continue in effect pending the issuance of the mandate of this
Court.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
-
No. 87-453. Amerada Hess Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Direc-
tor, Division of Taxation, New Jersey Department of the Treasury; and
No. 87-464. Texaco, Inc. and Tenneco Oil Company, Appellants v.
Director, Division of Taxation, New Jersey Department of the Treas-
ury. Appeals from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. In these cases
probable jurisdiction is noted. The cases are consolidated and a total of
one hour is allotted for oral argument. Justice O'Connor took no part in
the consideration or decision of these cases.

OPINIONS
No. 86-1520. Ann McLaughlin, Secretary of Labor, Petitioner v.
Richland Shoe Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Jus-
tice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 85-1765. Bankers Life and Casualty Company, Appellant v.
Lloyd M. Crenshaw. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by
Justice White with whom Justice Scalia joins. Opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom Jus-
tice Scalia joins. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and con-
curring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Justice Stevens and Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1696. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Peti-
tioner v. Commercial Office Products Company. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Marshall. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join. Justice Kennedy took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86–1145. Timothy A. Patrick, Petitioner v. William M. Burget,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Justice Blackmun took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.

MONDAY, MAY 16, 1988
629
No. 86-684. California, Petitioner v. Billy Greenwood and Dyanne
Van Houten. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California,
Fourth Appellate District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeal of California for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Justice
Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 87-339. City of New York, City of Miami, City of Wheaton and
National League of Cities, Petitioners v. Federal Communications
Commission, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opin-
ion by Justice White.
No. 87-505. Chick Kam Choo, et al., Petitioners v. Exxon Corpora-
tion, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor announced by the Chief Jus-
tice. Concurring opinion by Justice White.
No. 86-1357. United States Department of Justice, et al., Petitioners
v. Kenneth Michael Julian and Margaret J. Wallace. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia with whom Justice White and Justice O'Connor join. Justice
Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 87–267. D. H. Holmes Company, Ltd., Appellant v. Shirley Mc-
Namara, Secretary of Revenue and Taxation of Louisiana. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 23, 1988
635
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1650. Roger Philip Brannon, Appellant v. Connie Randmaa.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Third District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-181. Patricia A. Dixon, Petitioner v. Westinghouse Electric
Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
v. Commercial Office Products Company, 486 U. S. — (1988).
-
No. 87-476. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Petitioner
v. Ocean City Police Department. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Equal Employment Opportunity
Commission v. Commercial Office Products Company, 486 U. S.
(1988).
No. 87-761. WCLR Radio Station, Petitioner v. Leo J. Rengers. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. The motion of Chamber of Commerce of the
United States, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of McLaughlin v.
Richland Shoe Company, 486 U. S. — (1988).

636
MONDAY, MAY 23, 1988
No. 87-1249. Plitt Theatres, Inc., Petitioner v. Sam T. Coston. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of McLaughlin v. Richland Shoe Company, 486 U. S. ——— (1988).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Duane J. Dwyer, Petitioner v. Crocker National Bank, et al.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.
No. A-851. Roy Todd Bates, Applicant v. Texas. The application for
stay of mandate addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-676. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard E. Server. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-679. In the Matter of Petros A. Kotsos. Petros A. Kotsos,
of Glenview, Illinois, having requested to resign as a member of the
Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on March 21, 1988, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-683. In the Matter of Disbarment of Walter M. D. Kern, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-685. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stephen N. Strauss. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. 86-1088. City of Canton, Ohio, Petitioner v. Geraldine Harris,
et al. The motion of International City Management Association, et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 87-470. Fort Wayne Books, Inc., Petitioner v. Indiana, et al.
The motion of Video Software Dealers Association for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of PHE, Inc. for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 87-746. Michael H. and Victoria D., Appellants v. Gerald D. The

ther herein in forma pauperis is granted.

APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 86-1856. Northwest Central Pipeline Corporation, Appellant v.
State Corporation Commission of Kansas, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Kansas. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
No. 87-980. Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians, Appellant v. Orrey
Curtiss Holyfield, et ux., J. B., Natural Mother and W. J., Natural
Father. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Further consid-
eration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hearing of the
case on the merits.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-1206. Kathryn Isabella Mesa and Shabbir A. Ebrahim, aka
Shabbir Azam, Petitioners v. California. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 87-1651. Massachusetts, Petitioner v. Douglas Oakes. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts
granted.
No. 87-1616. Katherine Jean Graham, et al., Petitioners v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. This case is
consolidated with No. 87-963, Hernandez v. Commissioner of Internal
Revenue, and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument. Justice
Brennan and Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.

and Industrial Commission of Ohio. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Ohio. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice White with whom Justice O'Connor joins.

Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia
announced by the Chief Justice.

certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
