(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1988
653
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 85-1429. American General Life and Accident Insurance Com-
pany, Appellant v. Carolyn Miller, et vir. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Mississippi. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy
would dismiss the appeal with respect to Question 1 for want of a sub-
stantial federal question; with respect to Question 2, they would dismiss
the appeal for want of a properly presented federal question. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 85-1799. Treadwell Ford, Inc., Appellant v. Clarence W. Camp-
bell, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy would dismiss the appeal with re-
spect to Question 1 for want of a substantial federal question; with re-
spect to Question 2, they would dismiss the appeal for want of a prop-
erly presented federal question. Justice Stevens took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86–107. Mobile Dodge, Inc., Appellant v. Danny R. Alford. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia
and Justice Kennedy would dismiss the appeal with respect to Question
1 for want of a substantial federal question; with respect to Question 2,
they would dismiss the appeal for want of a properly presented federal
question. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 87–294. Alabama Power Company, Appellant v. Brenda Louise
Cantrell. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1361. Ralph Diamond, Benjamin F. Nolan, Samuel Green-
stein, Barbara Kaiser and Benjamin Glass, etc., Appellants v. Mario

654
TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1988
Cuomo, Governor of New York, et al. Appeal from the Court of Ap-
peals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 87-1595. Edward J. Halloran, Appellant v. New York. Appeal
from the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York, First Judi-
cial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 87-1658. Troy Roger Cagle, Appellant v. Colorado. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 87-1670. Richard T. Durjak, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6741. Michael L. Trombley, Appellant v. Vermont. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Vermont. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6812. David L. Richardson, Appellant v. Kenneth Arnold,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1699. Gary Elliott, etc., Appellant v. Marcial Lewin, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Texas. The motion of appellee Hill-
crest Baptist Hospital for damages and double costs is denied. The mo-
tion of appellee Marcial Lewin for damages and double costs is denied.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 87-6613. Carl Dean Swift, Appellant v. Samuel A. Lewis, Direc-
tor, Arizona Department of Corrections. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Arizona. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly pre-
sented federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-6550. Don Durns, et al., Petitioners v. Bureau of Prisons,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The motion of petitioners
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-

TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1988
655
tiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of U. S. Department of Justice v.
Julian, 486 U. S. — (1988). Justice Scalia took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this case.
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-. Aaron Lee Jones, Petitioner v. Alabama. The motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by the petitioner is granted.
No. D-681. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Stuart Feldman.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-690. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Joseph Dorsey.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-709. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert J. Kantor. It is
ordered that Robert J. Kantor, of Asbury Park, New Jersey, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-710. In the Matter of Disbarment of Terrence J. Ford. It is
ordered that Terrence J. Ford, of Santa Rosa, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-711. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harvey William Harper.
It is ordered that Harvey William Harper, of Los Angeles, California,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-712. In the Matter of Disbarment of Abraham J. Brill. It is
ordered that Abraham J. Brill, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is granted. Defendant is
allowed sixty days in which to file an answer. The motion for a tempo-
rary restraining order is denied.
No. 86-422. David Carpenter, Kenneth P. Felis, and R. Foster Wi-
nans, Petitioners v. United States. The motion of petitioner Carpenter

TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1988
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis nunc pro tunc is denied. The mo-
tion of petitioner Carpenter for appointment of counsel nunc pro tune is
denied. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.

and
No. 87-614. Ronald W. Sappenfield, et al., Petitioners v. Indiana.
The motion of American Civil Liberties Union, et al. for leave to file a
brief as amici curiae in No. 87-470 is granted. The motion of Spartacist
League, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The
motion of American Booksellers Association, et al. for leave to file a
brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 87-826. Jerome F. Goldberg and Robert McTigue, Appellants v.
Roger D. Sweet, Director, Illinois Department of Revenue, et al.; and
No. 87-1101. GTE Sprint Communications Corporation, Appellant v.
Roger D. Sweet, etc., et al. The motion of appellant GTE Sprint Com-
munications Corporation for divided argument is denied.
No. 87-996. Coit Independence Joint Venture, Petitioner v. Federal
Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, as Receiver of FirstSouth,
F. A. The motion of Joseph M. Hudspeth for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument and for additional
time for oral argument is denied. The motion of United States League
of Savings Institutions for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral
argument is denied.
No. 87-1888. Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al. The motion of peti-
tioner to expedite consideration of the petition for certiorari is denied.

OPINIONS
No. 86-495. K Mart Corporation, Petitioner v. Cartier, Inc., et al.;
No. 86-624. 47th Street Photo, Inc., Petitioner v. Coalition to Pre-
serve the Integrity of American Trademarks, et al.; and
No. 86-625. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Coalition to Pre-
serve the Integrity of American Trademarks, et al. On writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Judgment reversed in part, affirmed in part and cases re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the judgment of this Court. Justice Kennedy announced the judg-
ment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to
Parts I and II-A, with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White, Justice
Blackmun, Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia joined, an opinion with
respect to Part II-B with whom Justice White joined, and an opinion
with respect to Part II-C with whom the Chief Justice, Justice Black-
mun, Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia joined. Opinion by Justice
Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice
Marshall and Justice Stevens join, and with whom Justice White joins
as to Part IV. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and dissent-
ing in part with whom the Chief Justice, Justice Blackmun and Justice
O'Connor join.
No. 87-654. New Energy Company of Indiana, Appellant v. Joanne
Limbach, Tax Commissioner of Ohio, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Ohio. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 86-6284. John T. Satterwhite, Petitioner v. Texas. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan joins and with

666
TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1988
whom Justice Blackmun joins as to Part II. Opinion by Justice Black-
mun concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
No. 87-82. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Appellant v.
James E. Mallen, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Northern District of Iowa. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the District Court for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 87-5277. Tony B. Amadeo, Petitioner v. Walter Zant, Warden.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 87-363. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Petitioner v.
Martin Exploration Management Company, et al.; and
No. 87–364. Public Service Commission of New York, et al., Petition-
ers v. Martin Exploration Management Company, et al. On writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Brennan. Justice White took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases.

Adjourned until Monday June 6, 1988 at 10 o'clock.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-7052. Son H. Fleming, Petitioner v. Walter Zant, Warden.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is granted pending
the disposition by this Court of the petition for writ of certiorari.
Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay termi-
nates automatically. In the event the petitiion for writ of certiorari
is granted, this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the
judgment of this Court. The Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice
O'Connor would deny the application for stay.
1

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1988
671
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
"
No. 87-1629. National Can Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Wash-
ington Department of Revenue; and
No. 87-1767. Tyler Pipe Industries, Inc., Appellant v. Washington
Department of Revenue. Appeals from the Supreme Court of Wash-
ington. The appeals are dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeals were taken as petitions for writs of cer-
tiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice White, Justice Stevens and Jus-
tice Scalia would note probable jurisdiction and set the cases for oral
argument.
No. 87-1708. James P. Tierney, et al., Appellants v. Planned Indus-
trial Expansion Authority of Kansas City, Missouri, et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
properly presented federal question.
No. 87–1811. Woodfin M. Voinche, Appellant v. United States De-
partment of Justice, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6725. Tom Neeley Mullis, Appellant v. United States Bank-
ruptcy Court for the District of Nevada, et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87–1840. Richard L. Solyom, et al., Appellants v. Maryland-
National Capital Park and Planning Commission, et al. Appeal from the
Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.

672
MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1988
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-667. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francis X. Smith. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-682. In the Matter of Disbarment of John F. Briscoe. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-688. In the Matter of Disbarment of Nelson Samuel
Magedman. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-695. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard L. Baltimore, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-713. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harry Lanier Beach
Foote. It is ordered that Harry Lanier Beach Foote, of Jackson, Missis-
sippi, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 87-6431. Wayne T. Schmuck, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that
Peter L. Steinberg, Esquire, of Madison, Wisconsin, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
No. 87-6704. Curtis L. Wrenn, Petitioner v. Commissioner of Inter-
nal Revenue. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 27, 1988, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a
petition for a writ of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules
of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens,
dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc.,
464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.

OPINIONS
No. 87-5565. Cherlyn Clark, Petitioner v. Gene Jeter. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh Office. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Superior Court of Pennsylva-
nia for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 87–259. Jonna R. Lingle, Petitioner v. Norge Division of Magic
Chef, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 87-920. Natalie Meyer, Colorado Secretary of State, and Duane
Woodard, Colorado Attorney General, Appellants v. Paul K. Grant, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 87-5002. Ellis T. McCoy, etc., Appellant v. Court of Appeals of
Wisconsin, District 1. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
join. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 87-5367. Ralph Mills, Petitioner v. Maryland. On writ of certio-
rari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not incon-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Justice
White. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy join.

MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1988
683
No. 86-1743. Monessen Southwestern Railway Company, Appellant
v. Gerald L. Morgan. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylva-
nia, Western District. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom
Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part
and dissenting in part with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 87-519. Gary D. Maynard, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. William
T. Cartwright. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
White. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Mar-
shall joins.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1988
689
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-896. Samuel Loring Morison, Applicant v. United States. The
application for continued release from detention presented to Justice
Brennan and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Brennan,
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun would grant the application.
No. A-906. Secretary of Commerce, et al., Applicants v. Kokechik
Fishermen's Association, et al.; and
No. A-907. Federation of Japanese Salmon Fisheries Cooperative
Association, Applicant v. Kokechik Fishermen's Association, et al. The
applications for stays of the mandate of the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit and for stay of the preliminary
injunction of the United States District Court for the District of Colum-
bia presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court are
denied.



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1988
691
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-1710. Barbara J. Branson, Appellant v. Los Angeles County
Civil Service Commission, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1734. John R. P., Jr., Appellant v. Debra L. B. Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of California, Fifth Appellate District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1080. Maryland National Bank, Appellant v. Maryland State
Department of Assessments and Taxation. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of Maryland. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 87-1728. Germantown Savings Bank, et al., Appellants v. City of
Philadelphia. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, East-
ern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-2035. The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company, Peti-
tioner v. George O. Aldridge and Daisy M. Aldridge. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Monessen
Southwestern Railway Company v. Morgan, 486 U. S. (1988).
–
No. 87-417. Gary Willoughby, Petitioner v. Central Illinois Light
Company. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further con-

692
MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1988
sideration in light of Lingle v. Norge Division of Magic Chef, Inc., 486
U. S.
(1988).
No. 87-723. William Dougherty, Petitioner v. Parsec, Inc., et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Lingle v. Norge Division of Magic Chef, Inc., 486 U. S. (1988).
-
No. 87-851. Roger Clark, Carl Bushey, Johnny Russell, Terry
Fisher and Bart Viglielmo, Petitioners v. Momence Packing Company.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Lingle v. Norge Division of Magic Chef, Inc., 486 U. S. ——
(1988).

Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The petition for writ of cer-

the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Lingle v. Norge Division of Magic Chef, Inc.,
486 U. S.
-
(1988).

judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Lingle v. Norge Division of Magic Chef, Inc., 486 U. S. — (1988).

consideration in light of Lingle v. Norge Division of Magic Chef, Inc.,
486 U. S. (1988).

for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-
tition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for
further consideration in light of Maynard v. Cartwright, 486 U. S.
(1988).
-
No. 87-5676. Roger Dale Hayes, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-
tition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for
further consideration in light of Maynard v. Cartwright, 486 U. S.
(1988).
No. 87-5824. Gregory Jones, Petitioner v. Maryland. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Appeals of Maryland for further consideration
in light of Mills v. Maryland, 486 U. S. — (1988).

States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded

-
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Maynard v. Cartwright, 486 U. S. (1988).

petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Idaho for further consideration in
light of Satterwhite v. Texas, 486 U. S. - (1988).
No. 87-6410. Baby Ray Bennett, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further consid-
eration in light of Satterwhite v. Texas, 486 U. S. — (1988).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-687. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kerry J. Nahoom, Sr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-714. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marshall Word Watkins.
It is ordered that Marshall Word Watkins, of Houston, Texas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-715. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles A. Youts. It is
ordered that Charles A. Youts, of Waco, Texas, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 106, Original. State of Illinois, Plaintiff v. Commonwealth of
Kentucky. The request of the Secretary to the Special Master for
approval of final accounting is granted.
No. 109, Original. States of Oklahoma and Texas, Plaintiffs v. State
of New Mexico. The motion of the Special Master for an order authoriz-
ing interim compensation and reimbursement of expenses is granted
and the Special Master is awarded $16,771.79.
No. 87-548. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. Independent
Federation of Flight Attendants. The motion of Chamber of Commerce
of the United States of America for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
is granted. The motion of Airline Industrial Relations Conference for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Cross-

MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1988
695
over Flight Attendants for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 87-746. Michael H. and Victoria D., Appellants v. Gerald D. The
motion of appellee for divided argument is denied.
No. 87-796. Cities Service Gas Company, et al., Petitioners v. Mobil
Oil Corporation, et al. The application for recall and stay of mandate
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is granted
pending this Court's action on the petition for writ of certiorari. If the
petition for a writ of certiorari is denied, this stay is to terminate auto-
matically. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be granted, this
stay is to continue in effect pending the sending down of the judgment
of this Court.
No. 87-1165. California, et al., Petitioners v. United States, et al.
The motion of petitioners to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 87-6219. Jose A. Perez, et ux., Petitioners v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied.
No. 87-6405. Phillip D. Tompkins, Petitioner v. Texas. The order of
May 16, 1988, granting the petition for a writ of certiorari is amended to
read as follows: "The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted limited
to Questions 1 and 2 presented by the petition. Justice O'Connor took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition."
No. 87-6471. John J. LaRocca, Petitioner v. Boardman Township,
et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until July 5, 1988, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition for a writ
of certiorari in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Jus-
tice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun, dissenting: For
the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928
(1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without
reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 87-1383. United States, Appellant v. Irwin Halper. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 87-1716. Granfinanciera, S. A., et al., Petitioners v. Paul C.
Nordberg, Creditor Trustee for the Estate of Chase & Sanborn Cor-

696
MONDAY, JUNE 13. 1988
poration, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit granted.
No. 87-7028. John M. Mistretta, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 87-1904. United States, Petitioner v. John M. Mistretta. The
motions of John Mistretta for leave to proceed in forma pauperis are
granted. The petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit before judgment are granted. The
cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 87–318. Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Division, United Technologies
Corporation, Petitioner v. Christine Baldracchi. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
denied.
No. 87-924. Henry J. Kaiser Company, et al., Petitioners v. Donald
Paige, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1988
OPINIONS
709
No. 87-5468. Samuel Bice Johnson, Petitioner v. Mississippi. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall
joins. Concurring opinion by Justice White with whom the Chief Justice
joins. Justice O'Connor concurs in the judgment.
No. 86-1431. Theodore J. Loeffler, Petitioner v. Anthony M. Frank,
Postmaster General of the United States. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice O'Connor join. Justice Kennedy took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-1824. Michigan, Petitioner v. Michael Mose Chesternut. On
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Michigan. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Justice
Scalia joins.
No. 87-336. Wilfried Van Cauwenberghe, Petitioner v. Roger Biard.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 87–498. Kevan Berkovitz, a minor by his parents and natural
guardians Arthur Berkovitz, et ux., et al., Petitioners v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 87-16. Richard D. Shapero, Petitioner v. Kentucky Bar Associa-
tion. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky. Judg-
ment reversed and case remaned to the Supreme Court for further pro-
ceeding not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice Brennan
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the
Court as to Parts I and II and an opinion as to Part III in which Justice
Marshall, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Jus-
tice White concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice

710
MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1988
Stevens joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join.
No. 87-157. Allied Tube & Conduit Corporation, Petitioner v. Indian
Head, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Bren-
nan. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice O'Connor
joins.

No. A-950. Edward R. Byrne, Jr., Applicant v. Robert H. Butler,
Sr., Warden. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall. Justice
Stevens would grant the application for stay.
No. 87-7185. Edward R. Byrne, Jr., Petitioner v. Robert H. Butler,
Sr., Warden. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 15, 1988
717
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-352. Sun Oil Company, Petitioner v. Richard Wortman and
Hazel Moore, etc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kan-
sas. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice
Brennan concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom the Chief Jus-
tice joins. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 86-1052. Volkswagenwerk Aktiengesellschaft, Petitioner v.
Herwig J. Schlunk, Administrator of Estates of Franz J. Schlunk and
Sylvia Schlunk, Deceased. On writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court
of Illinois, First District. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment with whom
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 87-354. Arizona, Petitioner v. Ronald William Roberson. On
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division Two.
Judgment affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom
the Chief Justice joins. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
No. 87–645. F. Clark Huffman, et al., Petitioners v. Western
Nuclear, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 86-805. Billy J. "B. J." Pinter, et al., Petitioners v. Maurice
Dahl, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens. Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.

718
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 15, 1988
No. 86-1294. William H. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence,
Petitioner v. John Doe. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed in
part, reversed in part, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part
and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia. Justice
Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Friday, June 17, 1988 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 17, 1988
719
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia; and
Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 87-367. Bendix Autolite Corporation, Appellant v. Medwesco
Enterprises, Inc. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opin-
ion by Chief Justice Rehnquist.
No. 86-1992. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Antolin Punsalan Pangilinan, et al.; and
No. 86-2019. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Bonifacio Lorenzana Manzano. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgments reversed and
cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Jus-
tice Blackmun concurs in the result. Justice Kennedy took no part in
the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 86-957. John A. Liljeberg, Jr., Petitioner v. Health Services
Acquisition Corp. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
White and Justice Scalia join. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 86-1387. John H. Mackey, et al., Petitioners v. Lanier Collec-
tions Agency & Service, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Justice Blackmun, Jus-
tice O'Connor, and Justice Scalia join.
No. 86-1042. City of Lakewood, Appellant v. Plain Dealer Publishing
Co. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice
White with whom Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor join. The Chief
Justice and Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.

720
FRIDAY, JUNE 17, 1988
No. 87-499. Charles R. Christianson, et al., Petitioners v. Colt
Industries Operating Corp. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals with instructions to transfer the case
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. See 28
U. S. C. § 1631. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
Adjourned until Monday, June 20, 1988 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1988
721
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87–170. William Copley, et ux., et al., Appellants v. Heil-Quaker
Corp., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The judgment is affirmed. Bendix Autolite Corporation
v. Midwesco Enterprises, Inc., 486 U.S.
-
(1988).
No. 87-1582. Frank Boring Fitzgerald, Appellant v. Montana De-
partment of Family Services, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Montana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented fed-
eral question.
No. 87-1654. James T. Carkulis, Appellant v. Montana, et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction.
No. 87–1802. Julie Vetter, Appellant v. City of Bismarck. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of North Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-6335. Albert L. Sivley, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87–1621. United States Internal Revenue Service, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Susan B. Long, et vir. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Church of Scientology v. Internal
Revenue Service, 484 U.S. (1987). Justice Kennedy took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
-

722
MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1988
No. 87-6760. Charlie L. Burr, Petitioner v. Florida. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Johnson v. Mississippi, 486 U.S. (1988).

No. A-610. Robert J. Neville, Applicant v. Milton Mollen, et al. The
application for an injunction addressed to Justice Brennan and referred
to the Court is denied.

application for stay and other relief addressed to Justice Brennan and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-928. Edith Mae Gracey, aka Mrs. J. Raymond Gracey, Appli-
cant v. C. Denson Day, et al. The application for injunction and other
relief addressed to Justice Kennedy and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-684. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marc G. Schultz. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-702. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Sierra. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-705. In the Matter of Disbarment of Roger George Seaman.
Roger George Seaman, of Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on April 25,
1988, is hereby discharged.
No. D-716. In the Matter of Disbarment of Louis Anthony Tirelli. It
is ordered that Louis Anthony Tirelli, of Spring Valley, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-717. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Joseph Alfieri. It
is ordered that Richard Joseph Alfieri, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-718. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank C. Morales. It is
ordered that Frank C. Morales, of Los Angeles, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-

turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 22, 1988
741
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-1685. Florida, et al., Petitioners v. Hughlan Long, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Blackmun con-
curring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 87-578. The Bank of Nova Scotia, Petitioner v. United States;
and
No. 87-602. William A. Kilpatrick, et al., Petitioners v. United
States. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall.
No. 86-1753. John Doe, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens.
No. 87-5546. Donald Gene Franklin, Petitioner v. James A.
Lynaugh, Director, Texas Department of Corrections. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Justice White announced the judgment of the
Court, and delivered an opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice
Scalia, and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in the judgment with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall join.
No. 87-526. Bobby Felder, Petitioner v. Duane Casey, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan.

742
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 22, 1988
Concurring opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O'Connor with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 87-5309. Bobby Lynn Ross, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens join.
No. 87-3. Randy Braswell, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Kennedy with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and
Justice Scalia join.
☑
Adjourned until Friday, June 24, 1988 at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 86-1781. Richard Schweiker, et al., Petitioners v. James
Chilicky, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice
Stevens concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 86-7113. Paula Kadrmas, et al., Appellants v. Dickinson Public
Schools, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Dakota. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 86–1970. Mississippi Power & Light Company, Appellant v. Mis-
sissippi ex rel. Michael C. Moore, Attorney General of Mississippi, and
Mississippi Legal Services Coalition. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Mississippi. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 87-626. Michael N. Sheridan, et ux., Petitioners v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice
White. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief Justice and
Justice Scalia join.

of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for

MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1988
745
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Kennedy.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 87-1412. Susan E. Davidson, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87-1829. Pre-School Owners Association of Illinois, et al., Appel-
lants v. Illinois Department of Children and Family Services, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87–1812. Petitioners Seeking to Incorporate Liberty Lakes, Ap-
pellants v. Village of Lindenhurst, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Illinois. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly pre-
sented federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 86-1813. V. L. Cooper, et al., Petitioners v. Frank K. Kotarski.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Schweiker v. Chilicky, 487 U.S. (1988).
-
No. 87–174. Edward O. Turner, Petitioner v. Elise D. McIntosh, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Schweiker v. Chilicky, 487 U.S.
Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun would deny certiorari.
(1988).
No. 87-382. State Tax Commission of the State of New York, et al.,
Petitioners v. Herzog Brothers Trucking, Inc., etc., et al. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York. The motion

746
MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1988
of Seneca Nation of Indians for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
denied. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of New York
for further consideration in light of proposed regulations formally
published for comment by the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance of
the State of New York on March 8, 1988.
No. 87-477. Albert J. Ferens, et ux., Petitioners v. Deere & Com-
pany. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Sun Oil Company v. Wortman, 486 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-682. Technograph Liquidating Trust, Petitioner v. General
Motors Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of Christianson v. Colt Industries Operating
Corp., 486 U.S. - (1988).
No. 87-687. Sessions Tank Liners, Inc., dba Southwest Tank Liners,
Inc., Petitioners v. Joor Manufacturing, Inc.; and
No. 87–916. Joor Manufacturing, Inc., Petitioner v. Sessions Tank
Liners, Inc., dba Southwest Tank Liners, Inc. On petitions for writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The petitions for writs of certiorari are granted. The judgment is
vacated and the cases are remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Allied Tube & Conduit Corporation v. Indian Head, Inc., 486 U.S.
(1988).
No. 87-937. Attorney General of New Jersey, Petitioner v. First
Family Mortgage Corporation of Florida, et al. The writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of New Jersey is dismissed as moot.
No. 87-1522. Richard Koontz, et ux., Administrators of the Estate of
Steven Koontz, deceased, Petitioners v. International Harvester Com-
pany. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Sun Oil Company v. Wortman, 486 U.S. (1988).

MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1988
No. D-698. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph R. McCoy, III.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-720. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Anthony
MacGuire. It is ordered that William Anthony MacGuire, of Orange,
Virginia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-721. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter Thomas Roman. It
is ordered that Peter Thomas Roman, of Dunedin, Florida, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 104, Original. State of New Jersey, Plaintiff v. State of Nevada,
The Nevada Public Service Commission and the City of Las Vegas, Ne-
vada. The motion of the Special Master for award of compensation and
for reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Special Master is
awarded $6,143.65 to be paid one-half by plaintiff and one-half by de-
fendants jointly. This case having been dismissed on stipulation pursu-
ant to Rule 53.1 of the Rules of this Court, it is further ordered that the
Special Master is hereby discharged.
No. 106, Original. State of Illinois, Plaintiff v. Commonwealth of
Kentucky. It is ordered that the Honorable Matthew J. Jasen, Retired,
of Buffalo, New York, be appointed Special Master in place of the Hon-
orable Robert Van Pelt, deceased.
The Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and conditions
for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceed-
ings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and
take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it.
necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit such
reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
No. 113, Original. State of Mississippi, Plaintiff v. United States. It
is ordered that the Honorable Walter P. Armstrong, Jr., of Memphis,
Tennessee, be appointed Special Master.
The Special Master shall have authority to fix the time and conditions.
for filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings,

MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1988
749
and with authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take
such evidence as may be introduced and such as he may deem it neces-
sary to call for. The Special Master is directed to submit such reports as
he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses,
including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be borne by the
parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
No. 86-1940. Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, et al.,
Petitioners v. Edward Lynn. The motion of respondent to dismiss writ
of certiorari as improvidently granted is denied. Justice Kennedy took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

appendix is granted.
No. 87-6958. Richard Rutherford, Appellant v. Securities and Ex-
change Commission. The motion of appellant for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Appellant is allowed until July 18, 1988,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to sub-
mit a statement as to jurisdiction in compliance with Rule 33 of the
Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Black-

750
MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1988
mun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in
Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would dismiss the
appeal for want of jurisdiction and, treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.

OPINIONS
No. 86-492. Delbert Boyle, Personal Representative of the heirs and
Estate of David A. Boyle, Deceased, Petitioner v. United Technologies
Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall and Justice Blackmun
join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 86-995. Michael F. Murray, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 86-1016. James D. Carter, Petitioner v. United States. On writs.
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1988
763
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Stevens and Justice
O'Connor join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice Brennan
and Justice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
No. 86-1512. Samuel R. Pierce, Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban
Development, Petitioner v. Myrna Underwood, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed in part, vacated in part and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice Brennan concur-
ring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Mar-
shall and Justice Blackmun join. Opinion by Justice White concurring in
part and dissenting in part with whom Justice O'Connor joins. Justice
Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 87-168. Russell Frisby, et al., Appellants v. Sandra C. Schultz
and Robert C. Braun. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice White
concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan
with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.

Adjourned until Wednesday, June 29, 1988 at 10 o'clock.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1988

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
OPINIONS
No. 86-6757. John Avery Coy, Appellant v. Iowa. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Iowa. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor with whom Justice White joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun with whom the Chief Justice joins. Justice Kennedy
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 86-2000. United States, Petitioner v. Ike Kozminski, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in
the judgment with whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 86-6139. Clara Watson, Petitioner v. Fort Worth Bank and
Trust. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Justice O'Connor delivered the judgment of the Court, the opin-
ion of the Court as to Parts I, II-A, II-B, and III, and an opinion as to
Parts II-C and II-D with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White and
Justice Scalia joined. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part
and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall join. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
No. 87-712. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, et al., Petitioners v. Massachusetts; and
No. 87-929. Massachusetts, Petitioner v. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary
of Health and Human Services, et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed in part, reversed in part, and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by Justice White concur-

766
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1988
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy join.
No. 86-6169. William Wayne Thompson, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. Judg-
ment is vacated and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals
with instructions to enter an appropriate order vacating petitioner's
death sentence. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom the Chief Justice
and Justice White join.
No. 86-637. Communications Workers of America and Its Locals
2100, 2101, 2108 and 2110, Petitioners v. Harry E. Beck, Jr., et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom
Justice O'Connor and Justice Scalia join.
No. 87-328. Randolph Riley, etc., et al., Appellants v. National Fed-
eration of the Blind of North Carolina, Inc., et al. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice
with whom Justice O'Connor joins. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring
in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Stevens con-
curring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 87-253. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Appellant v. Chan Kendrick, et al.;
No. 87-431. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Appellant v. Chan Kendrick, et al.;
No. 87–462. Chan Kendrick, et al., Appellants v. Otis R. Bowen, Sec-
retary of Health and Human Services, et al.; and
No. 87-775. United Families of America, Appellant v. Chan Ken-
drick, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the
District Court for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Jus-
tice Scalia joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens join.
No. 87–1279. Alexia Morrison, Independent Counsel, Appellant v.
Theodore B. Olson, Edward C. Schmults and Carol E. Dinkins. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1988
767
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia. Jus-
tice Kennedy took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
The Chief Justice said:
"I am authorized to announce that all cases submitted to the Court
for decision have been acted upon by the Court. All other matters
scheduled for Conference today will be released on an Order List to-
morrow at 10 o'clock. Accordingly, it is ordered that those cases re-
maining on the docket, but not ready for consideration, are continued to
the session of the Court beginning October 3, 1988.
The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in Octo-
ber, 1988, at which time the October 1987 Term of the Court will be
adjourned and the October 1988 Term of the Court will begin as pro-
vided by statute on the first Monday in October.
I speak for all members of the Court in thanking the Supreme Court
staff for their continued dedicated work during the Term."
☑
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.



(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1988
769
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Justice
Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, and Jus-
tice Kennedy.
Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 87-1750. William Irr, Jr., Appellant v. Kentucky. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 87-1884. Gwendolyn L. King, etc., Appellant v. Lonnie Kaplan,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 87–1866. A. Reginald Eaves, et al., Appellants v. Joe Frank
Harris, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 87–6363. David Alan Castillo, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Dissenting state-
ment by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 85-516. Vernice Dubose, et al., Petitioners v. Samuel R. Pierce,
Jr., Secretary of Department of Housing and Urban Development,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Pierce v. Underwood, 487 U.S. (1988).
-
No. 86-1055. Robert Price, et al., Petitioners v. International Union,
United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of
America, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States.

770
THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1988
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further
consideration in light of Communications Workers of America v. Beck,
487 U.S.
. (1988).
No. 86-1343. Robert James Tafoya, Petitioner v. New Mexico. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of New Mexico for
further consideration in light of Coy v. Iowa, 487 U.S. (1988). Jus-
tice Blackmun would deny the petition.
No. 86-1661. Battles Farm Company, et al., Petitioners v. Samuel R.
Pierce, Jr., Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Dis-
trict of Columbia Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Pierce v. Underwood, 487 U.S. (1988).
-
No. 87-251. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Serv-
ices, Petitioner v. Christine Russell. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
for further consideration in light of Pierce v. Underwood, 487 U.S.
(1988).
-
No. 87-893. Alston A. Emanuel, Petitioner v. John O. Marsh, Jr.,
Secretary of the Army, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Watson v. Fort Worth Bank and
Trust, 487 U.S. (1988).
No. 87-6129. Gregory Montecarlo Jones, Petitioner v. Mississippi.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Mississippi for further
consideration in light of Thompson v. Oklahoma, 487 U.S. (1988)
and Maynard v. Cartwright, 486 U.S. (1988).

THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1988
771
No. 87-6135. David Lee Powell, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further consid-
eration in light of Satterwhite v. Texas, 486 U.S. — (1988).
-
No. 87-6190. James W. Conley, Petitioner v. Wisconsin. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District III.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District III,
for further consideration in light of Coy v. Iowa, 487 U.S. - (1988).
No. 87-6639. Doy Bowie, Petitioner v. California. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Houston v.
Lack, 487 U.S. (1988).

THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1988
compensation and for reimbursement of expenses is granted and the
Special Master is awarded $101,129.97 to be paid one-half by Nebraska
and one-half by Wyoming.
No. 112, Original. State of Wyoming, Plaintiff v. State of Oklahoma.
The motion of Wyoming Mining Association for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Alabama Power Company for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion for leave to
file a bill of complaint is granted. The defendant is allowed sixty days
within which to file an answer.
No. 87–107. Brenda Patterson, Petitioner v. McLean Credit Union.
The motion of American Jewish Congress, et al. for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae, out-of-time, is granted.
No. 87-796. Cities Service Gas Company, et al., Petitioners v. Mobil
Oil Corporation, et al. The motion of the parties to defer consideration
of the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted.
No. 87-1346. Bonito Boats, Inc., Petitioner v. Thunder Craft Boats,
Inc. Charles Lipsey, Esquire, of Washington, D. C., is invited to brief
and argue this case in support of the judgment below as amicus curiae.
No. 87-1589. Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association et al. The Solicitor General is
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 87-1888. Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 87-7028. John M. Mistretta, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 87-1904. United States, Petitioner v. John M. Mistretta. The
motion of Solicitor General for divided argument to permit United
States Sentencing Commission to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for additional time for oral argument is granted and
20 additional minutes are allotted for that purpose to be divided as
follows: Mistretta-40 minutes; the Solicitor General-25 minutes; and
the United States Sentencing Commission-15 minutes.
No. 87-1911. Railway Labor Executives' Association, et al., Petition-
ers v. Guilford Transportation Industries, Inc., et al. The motion of pe-
titioner to expedite consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari
is denied.
No. 87-2049. Railway Labor Executives' Association et al., Petitioner
v. Chicago & North Western Transportation Company, et al. The motion.

THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1988
773
of petitioner to expedite consideration of the petition for a writ of
certiorari is denied.
No. 87-6980. Kenneth Michael Venturi, Petitioner v. California. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until July 21, 1988, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compli
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Brennan, Justice
Marshall, Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the
reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983),
we would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari without reaching the
merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 87–1224. Mark H. Oring, Appellant v. State Bar of California.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. In this case probable
jurisdiction is noted.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until the first Monday in
October, 1988, at which time the October, 1987 Term will adjourn.

THURSDAY, JULY 28, 1988
785
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 88-5174. James E. Messer, Jr., Petitioner v. Walter Zant, War-
den. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Mar-
shall with whom Justice Brennan joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Brennan, Justice White,
Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 87-796. Cities Service Gas Company, et al., Petitioners v. Mobil
Oil Corporation, et al. The joint application to vacate the stay entered
on June 13, 1988, presented to Justice White and by him referred to the
Court, is granted only to the limited extent that this Court's order of
June 13, 1988, granting the motion for recall and stay of the mandate of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in this case
pending this Court's action on the petition for certiorari, shall be modi-
fied in the following respect: the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit is authorized to remand the case to the United States
District Court for the District of Kansas for the sole purpose of deter-
mining whether the settlement should be approved. The District Court
is authorized only to carry out the necessary proceedings to determine
whether the settlement should be approved, and either to disapprove
the settlement or to enter the appropriate orders disposing of the case
if the settlement is approved. If the settlement is disapproved, then
this Court's order of June 13, 1988, remains in effect without further
modification. This Court's order of June 30, 1988, granting the motion
to defer consideration of the petition for certiorari in this case, remains
in effect without modification.
